title: Travellers barred from whole towns Draconian laws used in new crackdown
story: The &ldquoblanket injunctions, which mean anyone pulling up on affected sites can be arrested, jailed or fined, can effectively ban travellers from entire boroughs.Councils applying for the orders have given the High Court witness statements and photographs of commercial waste, including asbestos, excrement and damaged locks from vacated sites.Previously, councils have reacted to traveller incursions, but they can now outlaw them before they happen.Nearly 20 authorities across London, Essex, Hampshire, Surrey, the West Midlands and Lancashire now have interim or blanket injunctions, with more believed to be preparing applications.                Traveller crackdown: Tory MPs urge new law to move camps on QUICKLY                Travellers leave rubbish and human FAECES in children's play areaGipsy and traveller organisations have slammed the new power, claiming it will prevent their nomadic way of life.Sarah Sweeney of Friends, Families and Travellers said: &ldquoWe are deeply saddened to hear that increasing numbers of councils are using injunctions to prevent gipsy and traveller families from stopping in their area.&ldquoLocal authorities have largely failed to identify land for families to stop so it should come as little surprise when they pull up in public spaces and on private land.A spokesman for the Community Law Partnership, which has represented travellers for several years, said: &ldquoWe think these wide injunction actions, which are becoming more common, are potentially highly challengeable.Caravans in a M&ampS car park in Camberley, Surrey (Image: STEVE REIGATE)London Borough Sutton is the latest to obtain the power, following a series of costly clean-ups after incursions in recent weeks.The High Court has granted an interim injunction order for three months, banning caravans from 182 sites, before a full application is heard.The injunctions ban named iniduals and &ldquopersons unknown from parking caravans and vehicles and dumping waste in areas they cover.If all councils were granted the power, it could effectively see an end to the bulk of unauthorised camps.Harlow council in Essex, which has two permanent traveller sites, was the first to get the ban, protecting 322 sites, in March 2015, after 109 incursions in 18 months.Council leader Mark Ingall said: &ldquoThis has had the effect of significantly reducing the number and duration of unauthorised encampments and the clean-up costs.It quickly resolves any issues, usually within 24 hours.Basildon in Essex secured one last November and councillor Kevin Blake said: &ldquoThere has been a marked reduction in the number of encampments with no incursions since March this year.20 authorities now have interim or blanket injunctions (Image:  )Greenwich in South-east London now has 203 parks and open spaces protected.A spokeswoman said: &ldquoIt has been hugely successful. There has only been one incursion since the ban was put in place.Redbridge, in east London, saw 40 incursions in 2007.But since securing an interim injunction in June, covering 235 sites, it has seen just one incident on council land, with culprits moved on within two hours, and another on private land.

title: A church on every estate
story: The project is backed by the Archbishop of Canterbury (Image: )A church on every estate in the UK is the ambitious new vision of the Church of England.The project, backed by the Archbishop of Canterbury, will see residents on large estates receive help to set up and lead the new churches.It aims to bring Christianity and church life to communities which might not otherwise attend standard services &ndash and help tackle the rise in violent crime.Community centres, cafes and schools will be used as bases for worshippers to meet.                Fury as Archbishop of Canterbury hails European Union in new speech                 Archbishop of Canterbury says HIGHER taxes should fund NHS Thriving church estates have already sprung up around the UK and church leaders say they build stronger communities.The Bishop of Burnley, Philip North, chairman of the Archbishops&rsquo Estates Evangelism Task Force, said: &ldquoThe vision is a thriving, loving Christian church on every single large estate. &ldquoThat&rsquos not a building &ndash we&rsquore talking about church as community of people.&ldquoSometimes it will be in a church building, but often it might be in a community centre or in a school or a large cafe. &ldquoThat&rsquos the vision a thriving Christian community on every estate.Estate residents will be trained to lead the churches, including the possibility of ordination.The project is part of the CofE&rsquos expecting people to come to us but for us to go to them.Bishop North believes the presence of a church on an estate can address the issue of violent crime by creating strong communities. &ldquoWhat the church does best is to build community and to build places where you can form a safe relationship.&ldquoWe can&rsquot solve those big cultural problems, but what we can do is offer iniduals spaces of safety and belonging where they can turn their lives around. That&rsquos where local churches are at their best.&ldquoWe talk the language of hope and we can answer some of these questions.People from all backgrounds can lead on estates, but if you want to plant a new church, that&rsquos best  (Image: )Bishop Thorpe said: &ldquoChurches on estates are close to those who live on estates.They are often the first to know about issues with young people and support young people. &ldquoAs Christians, we believe that God wants everyone to discover a relationship with him through Jesus Christ.So we need to go to every place, which includes places that many people don&rsquot go to, like estates.Speaking about one successful estate church in the north of England, Bishop North said: &ldquoOne of the key leaders in that church was addicted to heroin for 23 years and he gave it up when he found this church.&ldquoI asked him why and he said, &lsquoBecause I found somewhere where I felt safe&rsquo.You&rsquore seeing lives turned round and that&rsquos very exciting for church leaders.Renewal and Reform strategy.Bishop North said: &ldquoThe best person to plant a church on an estate is someone from that estate. Yes, I would have done it.He added that he would have replaced Meghan&rsquos dad but Prince Charles stepped in to fulfill the duty.Royal couple in love: Meghan and Harry at the polo earlier this summer (Image: )Harry and Meghan were reported to be heading to the US this summer to help build ties between America and Britain.Details are yet to be finalised.However, at the time Canadian sources said: &ldquoThe Canadian Foreign Office has heard about the tour and would love to have them stop there.&ldquoThis may very well become a North American tour.Meghan Markle fashion: Duchess of Sussex's style evolution in picsMeghan Markle LET DOWN by Kensington Palace over father Thomas MarkleLast week, Thomas Markle, 74, branded the Royal Family cult-like in a controversial outburst.Meghan's father compared the Windsors to Scientologists and said he believed they should be more open.He told The Sun: If they hear anybody say anything they just lock the doors. title: Brexit news MPs Expenses Members of Parliament Westminster news IPSA staff employed
story: MPs are calling for more money to pay their staff amid increased workloads due to Brexit (Image:  )The Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority (IPSA) told The Daily , Members of Parliament had been lobbying for a larger expenses budget - the money they receive to pay their employed staff.The MPs have stated they need extra funding to cope with the pressures and heightened workload associated with Brexit.In its annual report of its survey of MPs, published this month, IPSA said: &ldquoThere were further requests to further increase MP staffing budgets due to their increasing workloads, some of which is the result of Brexit.The watchdog would not rule out granting the requests and said it would &ldquotake into account any relevant consequences of the UK&rsquos decision to leave the European Union when considering any changes to the rules on MPs&rsquo expenses.                May DISMISSES calls for Brexit deal vote A former Tory minister told The Daily : &ldquoWe should not be increasing the budgets of MPs because of Brexit - that would be ridiculous.&ldquoAt a time when there are plenty of constraints on the public purse, this is just extraordinary.&ldquoIt shows a basic lack of political judgment and how out of touch MPs are with the British public, who just want Brexit done and delivered.The former minister also queried how such expense raises based on Brexit could be appropriately vetted.IPSA was established in 2009 largely in response to the MPs' expenses scandal  (Image: )They said: &ldquoIt could be open to abuse.&ldquoHow will it be possible to ensure the money is spent on Brexit, as opposed to just spending the money on different things?The news has exposed a system open to abuse, a former non-departmental public body&rsquos chairman has argued.Sir Alistair Graham, the former chairman of the Committee on Standards in Public Life, said: &ldquoIt is open to abuse, there has to be a guarantee of what the money is going on.&ldquoBrexit sounds like a rather convenient argument for increasing funding, IPSA should be very cautious about raising budgets.                No Deal is 'SO RADICAL' Britain will NOT do it: France mocks UK                 Brexit WARNING: Tough EU rules could see bloc snatch MORE banking jobs&ldquoIt would be quite wrong to automatically agree to an increase in the staff budget if there&rsquos a danger that some of it just goes to improve the family income rather than as a service to the public.&ldquoI have always been opposed to MPs being automatically able to employ their spouses.&ldquoAll MPs&rsquo positions should be subject to open competition.More than 150 MPs currently employ their wives, husbands and other &ldquoconnected parties as staff.A total of 152 MPs - almost a quarter - employed their relations in 2016-17 (Image:  )A total of 152 MPs - almost a quarter - employed their relations in 2016-17, at a cost of nearly &pound4million to the public purse.And, at present, MPs can spend &pound150,900 a year on staffing costs, rising to &pound161,550 in London.But the budgets can be increased - more than 100 MPs successfully applied to do so in 2016-17.Those MPs who applied for a raise increased their budgets by as much as &pound180,000 through supplementary requests.Sir Kevin Barron, chair of the Committee on Standards, said: &ldquoIt is essential that IPSA achieve value for money as we are all funded by taxpayers&rsquo money.&ldquoRequests for contingency funding should be judged inidually on their merits but only awarded where the need is clear.IPSA did not disclose the names of those MPs who had asked for additional funding for staffing costs as a result of Brexit.

title: Reunited Lancashire couple Ron Owen Ruth Hold wed after 60 years
story: Ron Owen, 84, and Ruth Holt, 79, met in the 1950s and dated for a year.But Ron wanted to travel the world and pursue his singing career as Ronnie Ray.For Ruth he was &ldquoalways the one and she couldn&rsquot believe it when he moved in near her &ndash 60 years on.She said: &ldquoWe started talking straightaway and it was like we had never been apart. We met up a few times for a chat and a drink and it went from there. I couldn&rsquot believe I had found him again.                Widow reunited with heartfelt message from her RAF serviceman husband                Wedding ring I lost at cricket found in pitch.&nbspRon, then 23, became a cruise ship entertainer while Ruth, 18, married and moved to Saudi Arabia. The grandmother added: &ldquoI have always thought about him and where he was, what he was doing. &ldquoAround six years ago I saw his name appear in a local newspaper. I have never heard of someone marrying after so long apart, I never thought it would happen. &ldquoI thought the world of him when we were together. He was always the one for me.&nbspRon Owen as he once was.  (Image: BLACKPOOL GAZETTESWNS )A young Ruth Holt  (Image: BLACKPOOL GAZETTESWNS )Ron, who loves to sing the hits of Matt Monro and Frank Sinatra, never married, and mother-of-two Ruth has been alone since her orce in 1983. He proposed to her last month and they are now planning their wedding next month near their home in Lytham St Annes, Lancashire. He said: &ldquoWe were watching telly and I just turned around to her and said &lsquodo you want to get married?&rsquo She nearly fell off the settee. I&rsquom looking forward to it but I must admit I&rsquom a little bit nervous.

title: Manchester Girl 12 race against time raise 60 000 for spine operation
story: Scoliosis sufferer Violet with her worried mother Gaynor  (Image: ZENPIX)Violet Mullin faces a race against time to raise the &pound60,000 needed for a groundbreaking operation &ndash which is not available in the UK &ndash to straighten her backbone.The 12-year-old&rsquos spine has curved 80 degrees since being diagnosed with scoliosis last year.Pain has left her unable to walk and struggling to breathe as her spine is crushing her lungs.Her mother Gaynor, 46, said she first noticed a problem with Violet in February last year.&nbspGaynor said: &ldquoShe was sitting on my knee when I noticed her shoulder was slumped to one side. I told her to sit up straight and she told me that she was.&ldquoI could see then that there was a bend starting in her spine. I wasn&rsquot worried initially because I&rsquom a yoga teacher and I thought it could be sorted.Violet was taken to the GP and referred to Manchester Children&rsquos Hospital where doctors diagnosed her with a severe scoliosis &ndash an abnormal twisting and bending of her spine.Scan of Violet&rsquos S-shaped backbone (Image: ZENPIX )When Violet was diagnosed in May last year the curve was at 52 degrees, but that has increased massively to 80 degrees.Gaynor, who lives in Manchester with Violet&rsquos stepfather James, 48, and her daughterRachel, 14, said: &ldquoI didn&rsquot realise how aggressive this condition can be in a youngster.&ldquoShe has gone downhill over the last few months and now can&rsquot walk because of the pain and she is also starting to struggle to breathe properly.&nbsp                Sea krill helped mend my curved spine...now I&rsquom a bionic mermaid                David Haye reveals secret spinal nerve injury left him unable to WALK&ldquoShe has to have the operation done now as she only has a window of opportunity while she is still growing and before her spine starts to stiffen.Traditional fusion surgery available on the NHS uses steel rods to straighten the vertebrae but it is highly invasive and leaves sufferers unable to bend their back and their spine is unable to grow further.Violet&rsquos family have pinned their hopes on an operation available in Barcelona called vertebral tethering.Surgeons attach nylon rope all along the spine with screws to produce the right tension needed to correct the curve.Gaynor said: &ldquoIt&rsquos an amazing operation. The nylon rope acts as a support to the spine. It&rsquos a less invasive surgery that still allows the spine to grow.She added: &ldquoIt really is a race against time to get it done. She has been so brave &ndash even though she is in a lot of pain, she&rsquos always got a smile for everyone.The family have raised more than &pound31,000 towards the operation but they still need to raise another &pound29,000.Gaynor added: &ldquoWe can&rsquot give up on her. We need Violet to have this opportunity.

title: BBC Weather forecast news Met Office heatwave London latest next week storm Ernesto
story: BBC Weather warned Storm Ernesto could cause parts of Britain to be hit with gale force winds over the weekend.BBC Weather meteorologist Alina Jenkins said: &ldquoThis is the remnants of what was ex-tropical Storm Ernesto. That will pep up the rain overnight. For much of England Wales through this after &ndash although a lot of clouds it should be mainly dry.&ldquoThe odd spot of rain perhaps for parts of Wales and south west England. The far north of Scotland sunny spells and a few showers. Some sunshine getting across to eastern parts of Scotland too.&ldquoBut it&rsquos the western isles of Scotland which will continue to see some stronger gusts &ndash&nbspgale force for a time &ndash and also quite gusty winds along western and channel coasts through this afternoon.                BBC Weather warn tropical Storm Ernesto will pound Britain                UK weather: Met Office weather map reveals where Ernesto will hitOn Saturday night the remnants of ex-tropical storm Ernesto will become more apparent with &ldquopersistent spell of rain arriving in Northern Ireland, north Wales, northern England and central parts of Scotland.Ernesto, which formed in the mid-Atlantic, is described as a post-tropical cyclone &ndash a weather pattern which can bring property-threatening 40mph winds and drenching downpours.The powerful wind created by the storm also harnesses enough power to create damage roofs and bring down power lines.Weather experts advise to make sure all loose objects outside are secured and to postpone any unnecessary trips as the strong winds will make driving hazardous.The BBC forecaster said that further south it will be dry but a &ldquowarm and muggy night.Sunday afternoon is mostly dry.The BBC forecaster said: &ldquoAcross much of England and Wales it is another very humid feeling day. Temperatures up to 23 or 24C. Cooler and fresher for the far north of Scotland.She added: &ldquoAs you go into the new working week fronts pushing their way eastwards but leaving a legacy of cloud.&ldquoAnd this front will continue to generate further shower outbreaks of rain across parts of Scotland, Northern Ireland and some of those showers likely to extend their way down into parts of Northern England.&ldquoHead further south and it is mainly dry. Again, quite a bit of cloud but we should see bright and sunny spells through the afternoon.BBC Weather forecast temperatures will pick up in the UK next week  (Image: WXCHARTS)&ldquoWe are still holding on to that warmth and humidity, particularly across England and Wales with temperatures here getting up to 25C.Temperatures could reach as high as 26C in London while Cardiff is at 21C and Edinburgh 19C.The Met Office revealed that temperatures could soar even further next week as a change in the jet stream threatens a huge shake-up in the weather system once again.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern warned there is &ldquohuge uncertainty about the weather in Britain next week, with either the possibility of more unsettled and rainy conditions or scorching heatwave temperatures.BBC weather forecast: Temperatures expected to hit 26C in London on Monday (Image: BBC&bull)Speaking in the Met Office 10 day weather forecast, Mr McGivern said: Computer simulations are picking up on something that is just happening thousands of miles away over to the west of the North American continent.&ldquoThe big ridge in the jet stream here could start to happen and if that happens then it will have big downstream consequences on the weather at home because this ridge will then ripple all the way across North America, the&nbspnorth&nbspAtlantic and then under close to the UK.&ldquoIf we end up on the south of this ridge we will have similar weather to what we had earlier in the summer &ndash the heatwave, the dry, the heat, the high pressure.&ldquoBut if we end up for the north of the jet stream we will end up with&nbspvery&nbspunsettled weather.BBC weather forecast: Temperatures to hit high 20s next week (Image: WXCHARTS)Met Office forecast Becky Mitchell also said that hot, humid air will drift in from Europe, bringing temperatures into the high 20s.Mitchell told viewers: More humid air will hang around the more central and southern areas. This will mean highs of 28C on Tuesday.Further pulses of warm air will drift across southern parts of the UK through the week. At the same time, fresher conditions can be seen across the north next week.By Friday, this fresher air does sink itself south, with temperatures back to around average.

title: UK weather forecast met office heatwave latest hot weather bank holiday weekend
story: Muggy, humid conditions over the next few days will give way to a late-week chill before the thermostat ramps up again later next weekend.Britain could be in for another heatwave before the summer is over with some experts predicting unusually warm weather well into autumn.Tropical air left in the wake of ex-tropical storm Ernesto&rsquos weekend visit will push temperatures to 28C (82.4F) by Wednesday.The arrival of chilly winds will see temperatures plummet by almost 10C across Britain by the end of the week, experts say.South-eastern England will hold onto the warmer weather until Thursday before the whole country takes on an autumnal feel.UK hot weather forecast: Britain will return to 28C temps this week (Image: NETWEATHER)Summer will then make a fiery return next weekend with swathes of the country in for a blast of bank holiday sunshine, according to long-range forecasters.Exacta Weather&rsquos James Madden said: &ldquoThere will be a cooler and more unsettled couple of days later this week as winds come in from a more westerly direction.&ldquoAny unsettled weather will be replaced by a more favourable pattern as we head into the bank holiday weekend, higher temperatures and summery conditions are likely to dominate the last few days of summer.&ldquoThere is also very high confidence that we could see another heatwave during the final few days of the month and into the start of autumn.                'Unusual hurricane' could RAVAGE the US for first time in 150 YEARS                Long range weather forecast shows Britain could BAKE AGAIN&ldquoThis could bring some lengthy periods of late summer sunshine with exceptionally warm to hot temperatures for the time of the year.&ldquoThere is a high chance that this summer could go down as one of the hottest on record, if not the hottest ever.Weather models show ground temperatures nudging 31C (88F) across southern Britain next Monday and through the start of the following week.Scotland and northern Britain are likely to be cooler with thermometers expected to hover in largely in the high teens perhaps briefly touching 20C (68F).UK hot weather: Warm temperatures are expected to arrives at the Bank Holiday Weekend as well (Image: NETWEATHER)It comes as the Met Office confirms summer 2018 could turn out to be one of the warmest on record after months of scorching sunshine.Government weather analysts say June was the third warmest on record while July came second in records going back to 1910.With a mean temperature so far of 16.1C (60.98F), this summer is on par with the record-breaking scorcher of 2006.Even if the rest of August turns out to be cooler than current forecasts suggest, summer 2018 will still finish in the top five, according to the Met Office.Dr Mark McCarthy, head of the Met Office National Climate Information Centre, said: &ldquoThe mean temperature measure gives a fuller picture of what the UK climate is doing.&ldquoOn this measure it&rsquos clear that the meteorological summer of 2018 is exceptional, simply for the consistent levels of warmth seen throughout the period so far.The average maximum temperature so far this summer for the UK is 21.1C (69.98F) with an average mean of 16.1C (60.98F).The UK has received just half the normal rainfall over the past three months with around 110 per cent of the usual levels of sunshine, according to Met Office figures.Government forecasters say the mercury will rise through the next few days as tropical air floods into Britain.Temperatures will take a dip again at the end of the week leaving much of the country feeling fresher by Friday.Met Office meteorologist Craig Snell said: &ldquoThe remnants of Ernesto have allowed the winds to switch to coming from a southwesterly direction so we will be importing tropical maritime air into the country.&ldquoMonday is likely to be quite warm and humid with temperatures reaching 25C (77F) or 26C (78.8F) in southern Britain although there will be a good deal of cloud around.UK hot weather: Next Monday's temperatures heats of up to 31C (Image: NETWEATHER)&ldquoThere will also be showers in parts of the country and we expect to see a similar picture on Wednesday although it could be warmer with temperatures reaching 28C (82.4F) in some parts.Southeastern England will remain in the steam-bath through Thursday while a cooler airmass brings temperatures down elsewhere, he said.The whole of the UK will feel fresher by the end of the week with thermometers expected to hit a maximum of 20C (68F), he added.He said: &ldquoSome places will drop to low single figures overnight at the end of the week and there will be further rain around.&ldquoA showery regime will continue into Saturday although it will start to turn drier.&ldquoThe cloudier picture at the start of this week is mainly due to tropical air over the UK which contains moisture coming in off the Atlantic.&ldquoHigh pressure will build through the week so there is a chance of seeing more in the way of sunshine and clearer skies.WeatherAction forecaster Piers Corbyn said much of the country will be wet and windy in the run up to the weekend.                BBC Weather forecast: GALE FORCE winds to hit UK before heatwave                 'Unusual hurricane' could RAVAGE the US for first time in 150 YEARSHowever a blast of baking sunshine could plunge parts of Britain back into a late summer heatwave in time for the bank holiday, he added.He said: &ldquoThere is a risk of some major storms later this week particularly in Scotland and northern England, elsewhere it will be drier although there will still be a risk of wind and rain, possible some thunder and hail.&ldquoBy the end of the month there are signs it will turn fine and very warm in the north of the country and hot towards the south with the chance of another heatwave building.&ldquoWhile it is likely to be very warm, there will be variable amounts of sunshine to end the month.Hot weather UK: Charts show temperatures picking up over the course of the week (Image: WXCHARTS)The Met Office's longer-range outlook predicts wet and windy weather to hold out into next weekend with the southeast turning warmer.It states: &ldquoOn Friday and Saturday many places will have sunshine and showers.&ldquoThese showers heavy at times and with a risk of hail and thunder, particularly in the north, with the best of the sunnier spells in the southeast.&ldquoThrough the rest of the weekend and into the following week the northwest will have showers or longer spells of rain at times, with drier and brighter conditions generally in the southeast,.&ldquoTemperatures starting rather cool, but recovering to around normal, and perhaps warm at times in the southeast.

title: Brexit news macron eu exit france no deal Alexandre Holyroyd
story: One of President Emmanuel Macron&rsquos MPs, Alexandre Holyroyd, told Politico that he was calm with regards to a no-deal Brexit as a degree of agreement is &ldquoinevitable and the most concerning issue for him is the government&rsquos in-fighting.Mr Holyroyd, who represents UK people living in France, said: &ldquoFrankly I don&rsquot think that there&rsquos a real concern in France about a no-deal.&ldquoThe idea of a no-deal seems so radical that it is difficult to imagine it.According to the World Trading Organisation, the economic costs for France if the UK crashes out of the EU without a deal are not huge.                Germany threatens to impose BORDER CONTROLS with FranceThe International Monetary Fund revealed last month that while the EU as a whole would suffer a 1.5 percent hit to its GDP, the cost to France would be just 0.2 percent.As time goes by, more and more top politicians have said that it is becoming more possible that there will be a no deal Brexit.The UK&rsquos Trade Secretary Liam Fox has said that there is a 60 percent chance of the UK leaving the EU without a deal.Alexandre Holyroyd has said France is not concerned about a no-deal Brexit  (Image: Rex*)Theresa May visited Macron for crunch Brexit meetings  (Image:  )Mr Holyroyd also said: &ldquoThe most concerning issue is that we might end up in a difficult situation because of the very complex political balance in the UK.It is difficult to imagine a clear majority who could win there. Internal political calculations could undermine the final Brexit deal.Mr Macron is supporting a proposal led by the Tory MP George Freeman to create a new cross-party coalition of MPs who are opposed to a no-deal Brexit.Dominic Raab and Michel Barnier are trying to thrash out a Brexit deal  (Image:  )The French chief sent a letter to the Tory MP saying: &ldquoI would like to welcome your initiative and wish you all the best for the success of the new edition of this event.Theresa May cut short her summer holiday in Italy to meet with Macron at the end of July in a bid to persuade him to accept her Chequers deal.Mr Holyroyd met with David Lidington as part of his diplomatic work before Macron&rsquos summit with Mrs May.

title: lombok earthquake indonesia quake tremors bali tsunami
story: The United States Geological Survey reported that the latest quake hit north-north-west of the battered Indonesian island, at a depth of just one mile.The USGS initially said the quake measured 7.2, but subsequently revised this to 6.9.There was no immediate tsunami alert from the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center.In a tweet shortly earlier, Sutopo Purwo Nugroho of the Indonesian National Board for Disaster Management&nbspput the quake's magnitude at 7.0.He added: The earthquake was felt hard in East Lombok. Earthquakes were also felt in Bali, Sumbawa, East Java and Makassar.Lombok earthquake latest: Another quake hit this evening (Image: USGS)Data collection on earthquake impacts is still being carried out.He subsequently added: Aftershocks continued in Lombok. PLN electricity goes out all over Lombok.Dark conditions. East Lombok, North Lombok and West Sumbawa felt a strong shock with the intensity of the earthquake felt by the VI MMI (strong).We are still coordinating with the officers there.Sutopo added: &ldquoPitch black conditions. Lombok earthquake LIVE: Indonesia island hit by magnitude 6.9 tremor                Lombok earthquake: Red Cross SCRAMBLE to evacuate residentsSutopo also shared a video of bewildered-looking tourists outside a hotel in the east of the Island.The tremor follows another one earlier today measuring 6.3 which happened near the town of Belanting, which killed one and triggered a series of landslides.East Lombok resident Agus Salim said of the earlier one: &ldquoI was driving to deliver aid to evacuees when suddenly the electricity pole was swaying. I realised it was an earthquake.&ldquoPeople started to scream and cry. They all ran to the street.Lombok Earthquake: USGS said there has been a number of aftershocks (Image: USGS)Lombok: A USGS map showing the location of the latest 6.9 quake (Image: USGS)Many locals pleaded for information on social media.Ahmadhira wrote on Twitter: &ldquoI&rsquom in East Lombok. All the people have run out of home &amp making camp. Is it a new earth uake or main after shock from the last earth quake?&ldquoHow is the probability the new earth quake or after shock will be coming tonight?Conflicting estimates of the depth of the earthquake have been issued but USGS latest report was at around 4.9km below land.                Bali earthquake: What is the Ring of Fire? Is Bali earthquake prone?                Lombok earthquake LIVE: Indonesia island hit by magnitude 6.9 tremorIndonesia earthquake: The islands were also hit by this massive earthquake earlier today (Image: USGS)Endri Susanto, a children rights activist in Mataram, said: Everybody ran outside their house. They're all gathering in an open field, still terrified.People are traumatised by the previous earthquakes and aftershocks never seem to stop.Earlier this month, another quake measuring 6.9 caused devastation on the island, with 460 casualties reported so far.No tsunami alert has been issued over the latest earthquake.Pictures have surfaced of huge cracks in the road  (Image: TWITTER)This morning's earthquake saw reports of people running into the street screaming.Powerful tremors have hit the region since August 5 and displaced hundreds of thousands of people.Tens of thousands of homes have been damaged over recent weeks.The tremors have also sparked landslides and left hundreds of tourists stranded.

title: Bali travel latest indonesia earthquake lombok earthquake
story: Earthquakes are common in Indonesia due to its location on a series of tectonic plates, meaning Bali International Airport and Lombok International Airport often remain open and fully operational during an earthquake.But with many Brits having booked flights in advance to popular holiday hotspot Bali, the recent cluster of horror quakes have left many jet-setters wondering how the natural disasters will affect them.Here, Express provides you with everything you need to know.A series of earthquakes ranging from magnitudes 6.2 to 7.2 have battered Indonesia and its islands including Lombok, Bali and Java.                Google Maps: Creepy blue pools in Indonesia volcano                Indonesia earthquake: UK hol favourite Lombok hit by MASSIVE 7.0 quakeThe first on July 29 saw 16 people killed.This was followed by another three days later, with a series of aftershocks in the following days and weeks raising the death toll to 347.Up to 2,000 people have been evacuated and at least 1,400 have been injured triggering emergency intervention by the Indonesian Red Cross.The Foreign Office said at the time that extra flights were put in place to help British holidaymakers get home to the UK after buildings were flattened and cars shattered by falling debris.Earthquakes are common in Indonesia due to its location on a series of tectonic plates (Image: )                Lombok EARTHQUAKE: Indonesian island hit by 6.3 magnitude quake                 Lombok earthquake LIVE: Indonesia island hit by magnitude 6.9 tremorAfter the second quake, Indonesia&rsquos centre for meteorology, climatology and geophysics issued a tsunami warning, though this was retracted a few hours later.Bali's Ngurah Rai International Airport and Lombok International Airport are both operating flights regardless of the destruction and major tourist resorts in Bali remain open and fully operational.But the Foreign Office has issued advice against traveling to Bali.The advice, updated today after the latest quake, reads: &ldquoThere has been a series of earthquakes and aftershocks to the north-east of the island of Lombok since 29 July 2018.A series of earthquakes ranging from magnitudes 6.2 to 7.2 have battered Indonesia (Image: )&ldquoThese have resulted in casualties and damage to buildings and infrastructure, most severely in northern and western areas of Lombok, north of the capital Mataram, and in the Gili Islands, where there continues to be power outages and a lack of clean water.&ldquoIf you&rsquore in these areas, you should exercise caution, stay away from collapsed buildings, liaise with your travel companyaccommodation provider, and follow the advice of the local authorities. Where possible, keep your family and friends up to date with your situation and itinerary.Bookings for holidays to the Gili islands will likely be cancelled by travel operators due to the devastation making it virtually impossible to travel there.Though no travel restrictions have been placed on Bali and Lombok.Bali's Ngurah Rai International Airport and Lombok International Airport are open (Image: )Should holidaymakers want to cancel their booking and play it safe, they should check with their insurance provider regarding any refunds as while many travel operators may be lenient regarding the circumstances, others may not.

title: Lombok earthquake 2018 Bali Lombok Indonesia tremor felt in Bali Lombok earthquake today
story: A huge magnitude 6.9 earthquake has struck the Indonesian island of Lombok on Sunday, less than 11 hours after a 6.4 tremor.The quake struck at 9.56pm WIB (3.56pm BST), 2km south of Belanting in the north-east of the island.The tremor was felt as far away as the neighbouring island of Bali and in the south of Lombok.The quake comes two weeks to the day after another 6.9 earthquake struck and killed more than 460 people on Lombok.                Lombok earthquake: Red Cross SCRAMBLE to evacuate residents                Bali travel latest: Indonesia rocked by huge earthquakeIt struck at a depth of 25.6km (16 miles), despite initial reports by the US Geological Survey it had hit at a shallow depth of just 1km.National Disaster Management Agency spokesman Sutopo Purwo Nugroho said on Twitter the island had been struck by a series of aftershocks.After the initial magnitude 6.9 quake, the island was rocked just 20 minutes later by a 5.9 tremor, a 5.5 aftershock less than 15 minutes after that and a magnitude 4.9 earthquake on the Panjang Island, off the coast of Lombok.Communication with the island is poor, Mr Nugroho said as residents deal with &ldquodark conditions on the island.Lombok earthquake MAP: The quake struck 2km south of Belanting in the north-east of the island (Image: USGS )He wrote: &ldquoHopefully there will not be many fatalities and more severe damage.Teddy Aditya, an official at Indonesia&rsquos search and rescue agency, said: &ldquoI was in a restaurant when the shaking started. The lights went out, they are still out. Everyone is still outside, not going back in.&ldquoWe are urging the public not the panic and to stay away from buildings and big trees. We are also urging them not believe hoaxes and false information.Just hours earlier, the island was struck by a magnitude 6.3 tremor at 12.10pm local time (5.10am BST).                Lombok earthquake LIVE: Indonesia island hit by magnitude 6.9 tremorLombok earthquake MAP: The 6.9 tremor was followed by a series of aftershocks (Image: USGS )The tremor struck 6km north-east Sembalunlawang in East Lombok, the USGS said.Residents said the earthquake earlier in the day was felt strongly in the east of the island.East Lombok resident Agus Salim said: &ldquoI was driving aid to evacuees when suddenly the electricity pole was swaying.&ldquoI realised it was an earthquake. People started to scream and cry. They all ran to the street.Lombok earthquake MAP: The tremor was so strong it was felt in Bali (Image: USGS )In Bali, the latest big quake was felt for a few seconds, rattling windows and furniture.Lombok suffered damage running to more than 5 trillion rupiah ($342 million) from the August 5 earthquake, authorities said last week.More than 350,000 people fled their homes after the August 5 quake to shelter in government-provided tents or makeshift structures in open fields.Authorities said aid was slow getting so some of the hardest-hit areas as they are remote.

title: Iran news Iran s Foreign Minister accuses US addicted sanctions
story: President Trump imposed further sanctions on Iran earlier this month  (Image: )Talking to CNN, He said: &ldquoI believe there is a disease in the United States and that is the addiction to sanctions.&ldquoEven during the Obama administration the United States put more emphasis on keeping the sanctions it had not lifted rather than implementing its obligation on the sanctions it lifted.The US reimposed sanctions against Iran earlier this month amid heightened tensions between the two countries, after President Trump announced the US&rsquos withdrawal from the 2015 Iran Nuclear Deal in May.The first wave of sanctions curbed Iran&rsquos purchase of US dollars, its trading of metals, and its coal, industrial software and automotive industries.                Iran news: Tehran urges EU to RESIST US-imposed sanctions In an hour-long interview, Mr Zarif said the deal could still be honoured between the countries despite the recent rhetoric from President Trump.In a tweet, Trump said the deal was a &ldquohorrible one-sided deal that should never, ever been made.Mr Zarif still believes there are ways to achieve a healthy and peaceful relationship with Iran, but warned that President Trump is not co-operating fully.He said: &ldquoWe felt that the United States had learned that at least as far as Iran is concerned, sanctions do produce economic hardship but do not produce the political outcomes that they intended them to produce.Protests taking place in Iran over US pulling out of nuclear deal (Image: )&ldquoI thought that the Americans had learnt that lesson. Unfortunately, I was wrong.Mr Zarif did not commit to Iran signing a new nuclear deal with the US and said the possibility of a new deal is dependent on President Trump and whether he can prove he is a &ldquoreliable partner.The Iranian Foreign Minister also believes a meeting between President Trump and President Rouhani would not be effective at the current time.President Rouhani has equally previously stated that Iran &ldquoalways welcomed negotiations, but warned that the US would need to halt sanctions before future negotiations could take place.He said: &ldquoNegotiations with sanctions doesn&rsquot make sense.&ldquoThey are imposing sanctions on Iranian children, patients and the nation.&ldquoIf you&rsquore an enemy and you stab the other person with a knife and then you say you want negotiations, then the first thing you have to do is remove the knife.The diplomatic row is not likely to end in the near future, as President Trump intends to implement a second wave of sanctions in November, which are set to target Iran&rsquos oil and energy industries.Oil production is a significant part of the Iranian economy, accounting for one fifth of GDP.

title: labour mp refuses six times to say jeremy corbyn is fit to be pm and hints he could be ousted as leader next month
story: Madeleine Moon failed six times when asked to say if the Labour leader was fit to become Prime Minister.She blasted him for dominating newspaper headlines with negative coverage over his controversial trip to Tunisia in 2014.He has admitted he laid a wreath to honour members of the Black September terrorists who killed 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich 1972 - but refused to apologise to the widows for attending.After pictures emerged of him at the ceremony at a cemetery in Tunis, Mr Corbyn initially denied he was involved - saying he was marking the deaths of 47 people in Israeli airstrikes in 1985.But he has since changed his story several times, and now faces a House of Commons probe over failing to properly declare the trip to the authorities.The Labour boss has come under increasing pressure this week, which comes on the back of the partys ongoing anti-Semitism crisis.And today Ms Moon, the MP for Bridgend, hinted that Mr Corbyn could face moves to oust him as early as Labour’s annual conference in Liverpool next month.She told TalkRadio: “Individuals as leaders come and go. And the party will look at this I am sure extremely forcefully at the next conference.Lets wait and see what conference decides.“Theres always a rule in politics: if youre on the front pages for too long you become the story and thats not good because you miss all the good and effective things that the Labour Party is doing in terms of policy and holding this government to account.”Host Julia Hartley-Brewer asked her: “Do you think that a man who lays wreaths at the tombs of terrorists who have killed innocent people is fit to be the British Prime Minister?”But Ms Moon would only reply: “That will be a decision for the British people.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: scotland school term dates summer holiday end
story: But when exactly does your childs school holiday finish? And how can you check?School holiday dates in Scotland vary depending on the council the school is in.Helpfully, the Scottish government has made a website where you can check when the holiday ends.Just select your local council from the list, and it will tell you the dates.The link to the tool is here.School holiday dates in Scotland vary between the different local education authorities.They generally have an earlier summer break than the rest of the UK.Therefore they return to school in August rather than in September, which is the norm for England and Wales.In Scotland, schools broke up for the summer holidays around June 29.Some schools go back for the autumn term on August 14 or 15 with others returning on August 20 or 21, depending on in-service days.You should check your council website for the correct dates.Again, school holiday and term time dates can vary depending on which part of the country you live in.The dates below are just a rough guide, but check your local council website for the exact dates.Parents are only allowed to let their children miss school if they are sick.The Scottish government advises that schools will not normally give a family permission to take pupils out of school for holidays.However there are no fines for parents who do take their kids on holiday during term time.

title: we are finally showing brussels we can go it alone after brexit and not before time
story: The publication of “technical notices” outlining how life will continue more or less as normal if the EU refuses to do a deal with Britain for petty political reasons is a crucial boost to our negotiating hand.Compare this grown-up approach to what Brussels and some European leaders have been up to recently.The EU has accused MI6 of bugging our Brexit talks. And our “ally” across the Irish Sea, the rent-a-quote Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, is threatening to ground our planes the day we leave.The silly season is coming to an end but it seems only Britain is getting serious.There is still much to do if, as we suspect, Brussels has no interest in negotiating in good faith. They are so terrified by the collapse of their project, thanks to unrest everywhere from Italy to Poland, that they’re willing to make themselves poorer as a result.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab must get his department moving quicker and force other parts of government to speed up their preparation.But we are finally showing we can go it alone. Not before time.AMAZON appear to be launching another front in their all-out war to take over just about every bit of our lives, with plans for a comparison site.This doesn’t fill us with excitement. After all, in recent days we’ve learnt that Brits are being charged over the odds for their Prime subscriptions, a service which itself has been shown not to deliver on its “next day” promises.We’ve no problem with competition or businesses doing well. Good companies with good profits create good jobs.But they must play by the rules, especially when other firms — such as high street retailers — are struggling.It is still staggering to us that Amazon’s UK tax bill FELL last year despite it almost tripling its profits.The Chancellor must close the costly loopholes that tech giants continue to exploit.WE’RE saying a little prayer for the Queen of Soul.Aretha Franklin redefined the music landscape, her songs influencing everybody from Luther Vandross to Adele.But she also raised huge amounts of money for the civil rights struggle in the US, doing it not for publicity but because she believed in it.Her extraordinary take on Otis Redding’s Respect became an anthem not just for African Americans but for feminists the world over.Rest in peace.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madonna best at being madge
story: She might have had a bit of assistance to retain such a fresh-faced youthfulness, but the body is all her own work.Through hours of  gym graft and sheer willpower she’s even more bendy now than when she first burst on to the scene back in 1984 warbling Holiday in a Minnie Mouse falsetto.Madonna is the biggest-selling female artist ever, shifting 300million albums and is worth around 454million quid.She’s achieved success on her own terms and been a trailblazer for every other successful female act following in her wake. There would be no Katy Perry, Miley Cyrus or arguably Lady Gaga without Madonna.She might not be the best singer or dancer in the world, but she’s certainly the best at just being Madonna.You simply can’t imagine anyone ever telling her what to do. She’d laugh in their face.Madonna had always known how to grab attention, whether it’s publishing a book stuffed full of naked photos of herself, faking self-pleasure on stage, or kissing Britney Spears.And only Madonna could have bounced back from almost being strangled by her bright red Armani cape when she took a tumble and fell on her backside during the Brit Awards three years ago.She merely dusted herself down and carried on regardless, but I bet whoever was in charge of her wardrobe that night would have been given the b******ing of their life.Madonna is always in charge, professionally and personally. Even during her brief fling with aging lothario Warren Beatty, he was very much a bit player in the Madonna Show.That must have badly bruised the ego of a man who had always had the upper-hand in his relationships until then.It has to be said her love life hasn’t been anywhere near as successful as her career.There was a brief, destructive marriage to American actor Sean Penn in the Eighties and in 2000 she married Guy Ritchie, but the couple divorced eight years later.Since then she has dated a string of handsome and often young men, but they usually seemed to have the whiff of a photo opportunity about them rather than anything long term.She chews them up, spits them out and moves on to the next one.Madonna seems happiest as a single mum.She has uprooted the family to Lisbon, in Portugal,  because her adopted son David wants to play professional football.With her vast wealth she could easily have bought him a team such as LA Galaxy but she has always had a Calvinistic work ethic that she has tried to pass on to her kids.She has also made up with son Rocco Ritchie after a bitter custody battle and appears to be in a very good place.In an era where most young female vocalists all sound the same — bored, whiny and more than a wee bit yodelly — we really do need a one-off like Madonna.I hope she had a fabulous birthday on Thursday in Marrakech, Morocco, and danced until dawn to all of her greatest hits.Happy 60th birthday, ma’am, and I’ve no doubt you will still be in your fishnets and basques when you get that 100-year birthday message.Just when the royals and their advisers thought the whole fiasco between Meghan Markle and her dad had gone quiet, there comes a bizarre twist.Meghan’s rent-a-gob half-sister Samantha, who seethes with rage and jealousy, has announced that Thomas Markle is bringing out his own clothing range.This led to speculation as to what the brand might be called.  “Markle &amp Spencer” or “Primarkles”  (thank you, Alan Carr). But joking aside, surely this can’t be a serious  concept.Apart from being a crass, money-grabbing exercise cashing in on a quasi-royal connection, who on earth would buy garments from a pensioner who dresses like a hobo?I’ve had a great deal of sympathy for Thomas  in the past. He was treated poorly in the build-up to the  Royal Wedding, when his daughter married Prince Harry.He should have been embraced by his new family and given guidance on how to deal with the  media attention.Instead he was cast adrift. The result? Those stupid paparazzi set-up photos and a series of interviews that painted Meghan in a poor light.Every time her dad talks on TV or to newspapers and magazines, her popularity is dented.The two of them obviously have a fraught relationship. It turns out Thomas didn’t attend Meghan’s first wedding in 2011 either.Thomas increasingly comes across as bitter, angry and dislikable.To gain media attention he keeps making more and more outrageous accusations.My advice would be to stop listening to his bitchy daughter Samantha and maintain a dignified silence.All thoughts of profiteering through a clothing range or any commercial activity must be abandoned forthwith.That just might mean there could be some  sort of reconciliation in the future.Otherwise he will lose his daughter forever.ONE of the week’s most astonishing stories involved a young US woman who has been given her life back with a groundbreaking face transplant.Three years ago, Katie Stubblefield, from Mississippi in the US, tried to take her own life and shot herself in the face with a hunting rifle. She was just 18.Doctors saved her life but she was left with a mass of scar tissue instead of a face.Katie, the youngest person ever to receive a face transplant, endured more than 30 hours of surgery.Of course, the operation requires a donor – and in this case it is  a very sad story.Katie received the face  of a mum who died of a drug overdose.She was a registered organ donor and her grandmother bravely approved the donation.That decision can’t have been easy and we should always salute those who are donors, and the loved ones who give their consent.Katie won’t look like anything like her donor because the “face” is moulded on to her new bone structure.She continues to heal and  make progress, but this kind of surgery is still in its infancy.She will always look “different” but she has a second chance of life and now wants to help others in anguish and with suicidal thoughts.It’s an incredible story of despair that turned to  hope.  The skill and dedication of the team of surgeons and medics that helped her is awe-inspiring.I’m always surprised to learn that Caroline Flack is 38 years old.The presenter looks a  lot younger – and at the moment she is acting like a lovesick teenager going through the agony and ecstasy of her first serious crush.Her off/on romance with red carpet fever victim Andrew Brady is becoming laughable.This week the couple apparently had yet another spat in a London ­restaurant.If these two are to have any chance of staying together long term, they need to get out of the public eye and spend some quiet time alone.I’m sure Caroline knows of a certain Love Island that isn’t being used right now. That would do very well.The ending of the second series of The Handmaid’s Tale had me shouting in despair at my TV.I don’t want to give away too many spoilers but this cliffhanger will break your heart.It also, however, sets up season three for long overdue revenge.As always, astonishing performances from Elisabeth Moss as  June/Ofglen and Yvonne Strahovski as Serena Joy.They will soon fight it out for real when the TV actress awards are up for grabs.I’ve lost track of the amount of slippers our border terrier puppy Angus has chewed up, but this week he surpassed himself by getting his paws on his Pet Passport and virtually destroying it when we were in Spain.Luckily a  local vet issued him with a Spanish version and he now boasts dual nationality.He’s suddenly developed a liking for an afternoon siesta, but at least we were able to get him back into the UK – although who knows what will happen to him after Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: public realised leopard corbyn spots
story: If Corbyn wishes to deny the obvious that is his prerogative the notion you should be prepared to swallow any and every piece of whitewashing nonsense peddled by his fans is quite a different matter.“I was present” when the wreath was laid “but I don’t think I was involved in it” is, I suppose, a step forward from the Labour party’s previous suggestion that “The Munich widows are being misled. Jeremy did not honour those responsible for the Munich killings”.Holding a wreath should not be reckoned to be any kind of endorsement of the wreath we know Jeremy deplores this kind of thing and, indeed, all other forms of wreath.Hark, though, at how quickly the approved line may shift. What was a “smear” yesterday is a forgotten truth today, airbrushed from history because, well, that’s the way these people do these things.The new line is Jeremy wants to see “a fitting memorial to everyone who died in every terrorist incident everywhere”.I dare say he’ll be visiting Enniskillen soon. Of course.And yet, in one sense there really isn’t very much to look at. Or, rather, very little that is new. This is who Corbyn is and who he has always been.He has never bothered hiding this, leaving one to assume he only does so now because there is some small, nagging part of his brain which accepts it might be sensible to do so, since failing to hide it might prove politically inconvenient.Even so, he cannot change. Anyone who has been at university will recognise Corbyn and all his fellow travellers.These were the people — some of them clever but not many of them intelligent — who fouled student politics for everyone else.The chiselling parsers and pedants and revolutionaries whose appetite for procedural minutiae bored everyone else into submission.And usually that would be that. They would, most of them, grow up eventually. But not St Jeremy and not his devotional disciples, either.They are greyer now but as instantly recognisable as they always were: Experts in room-clearing.They ought, by rights, to be confined to dingy rooms above down-at-heel pubs, where they could cut and paste their thuddingly dreary newsletters. Instead, mystifyingly, they have been given control of one of Britain’s great political parties.How much will this summer of anti-Semitism really cut through with the average voter? Less than you might think, I suspect.In the first place — and this may be a good thing — Twitter remains a niche platform and political Twitter a niche even there.Secondly, the public have already made up their minds about Corbyn and they think he’s a dud.Each month YouGov asks whether Jeremy Corbyn or Theresa May seems the best available Prime Minister and each month Corbyn trails.Sometimes he is also beaten by “Don’t know”. That’s Corbyn: He can come third in a two-horse race.But, they splutter, look at what a kind and gentle and decent man he is. Why can’t other people see that he’s a valiant activist for peace?Possibly because, for a decent fellow, he spends a startling amount of time with thoroughly indecent people.He keeps falling in with the wrong crowd while never being a member of the wrong crowd himself. There is no need here to document the long list of unsavoury people with whom Corbyn has been happy to associate himself because, really, what is now the point? He is who he is and we know who he is.In Corbyn’s world every-thing has a single, simple explanation. Colonialism is the root cause of all root causes.That insight — if we can call it that — dictated his views on Ireland just as it dictates his views on the Middle East, Cuba, Venezuela and everywhere else.From there it is but a short leap to the kind of deluded wishful thinking that animates what passes for his thinking. Once you have assumed that Northern Ireland should not exist, you absolve yourself of any and all need to think about what should happen next.You may ignore the inconvenient, and stubborn, reality that Northern Ireland — like, well, Israel — does exist and is not going to disappear.Practical politics means wrestling with things as they are, not as you think they should have been decades previously.But if you start with the theory, you may avoid practical reality. If this leaves you with nothing — precisely nothing — useful to say then so be it. You will at least remain pure in heart.If this means you are no kind of “peace campaigner” at all, that’s fine too, because you will be shielded by your own impenetrable sanctimony.As poses go, this is an awfully comfortable one but it’s not serious politics.Perhaps Corbyn really is just unlucky. But it seems more probable that he’s not. And that, far from being the decent man of legend he’s actually thoroughly indecent.The only possible alternative is that he’s thunderously, crushingly, toe-curlingly thick.On balance, however, it seems more probable that he is, in fact, both.Enough of this. Enough, already.GOT a story? RING The Sun on 0207 782 4104 or WHATSAPP on 07423720250 or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: british voters give brexit verdict
story: Nearly half of Brits think we should leave the EU on March 29 with or without a deal, a Sun on Sunday poll reveals.They are sick of Brussels bullying and resistant MPs stalling — and simply want ministers to deliver.The mood of the nation is hardening after two years of bitter rows and fruitless negotiations since the historic referendum result.An overwhelming 62 per cent say they have not changed their minds. Those who have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave.Many people are deeply sceptical about the tedious stumbling blocks that have bogged down the process.Almost half — 48 per cent — think the political classes are deliberately making heavy weather of Brexit in the hope it will convince the public to change their minds.Six in ten believe the EU is out to punish the UK by refusing to compromise in talks on trade and free movement, our Deltapoll survey says.But the vast majority are convinced a departure deal will be hammered out in the end, even if it takes longer than expected.Former Cabinet minister Priti Patel last night said: “The Sun on Sunday’s poll shows that the British people ultimately believe we can build a stronger future for our country outside the EU.Nearly half of adults believe the weather goes in cycles and that heatwaves come around from time to time.Barely a third of voters believe the human race is responsible and that we will have more extreme temperatures unless we act soon.Our poll found that a majority of 18 to 24-year-olds blame global warming for the hottest British summer since 1976.But in every other age group, most people think it has little or nothing to do with climate change.Six in ten over-55s believe it was “just another hot summer”.“It is clear that most people are sick to the back teeth of being ­bullied by the EU and listening to politicians at home erecting all kinds of obstacles to prevent them honouring the referendum result.“The Government should sit up and heed the results of this poll. That means being tougher in negotiations with Brussels and doing what the nation voted for — to get Britain out of the EU.”Most people — 55 per cent — are against a second in-out referendum, according to our poll.Forty per cent think we should just leave in 222 days’ time as planned with or without a deal.Fifteen per cent want a vote on the final deal, but not a re-run on whether or not Britain leaves the EU.Overall, only 13 per cent have changed their minds on Brexit since the referendum on June 23, 2016. Most of those were once Remainers. Fifteen per cent of them admit to having shifted their view — equivalent to 2.4 million people.That compares with just 11 per cent of Brexit backers, 1.9 million, who have had a rethink.Ex-Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith said the poll had “nailed the lie” that many people regret voting Leave.Deltapoll director Martin Boon said the findings show most people are taking a tougher stance on Brexit.He added: “Half the public believe themselves to be under siege from the political classes trying to change their minds.“But the message they are sending back is that they haven’t changed their minds and the likelihood is they won’t.”Voters are evenly divided on whether there will be a hard border after Brexit. Twenty-two per cent say there will, 21 per cent say otherwise.There is also a split over whether leaving the EU will prove a historic mistake. Forty-four per cent think it will, 30 per cent believe it will not. One statement united 59 per cent of voters — “I’m really bored by Brexit.”Separately, our poll found that most people think former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson was right to raise the difficult and sensitive issue of women wearing burkas. Two-thirds believe he was right to start a debate about the Muslim veil.But some say he should say sorry because he went “over the top” by comparing wearers to “bank robbers” or “letterboxes”. Half of Tory supporters and 36 per cent of all voters believe his remarks were right and he has nothing to apologise for.A further 28 per cent say he went a little too far with his language and should admit it.He gets no support from 23 per cent, who say his remarks were offensive and he should say sorry.Deltapoll interviewed an online sample of 1,904 adults aged 18+ from August 14 to 16. Results have been weighted to the profile of all GB adults.The Labour leader has defied the odds after damaging revelations about the friends he keeps.Half of voters believe Labour has a problem with anti-Semitism. More than a third say Mr Corbyn is part of that problem.But a Sun on Sunday Deltapoll has Labour three points ahead of the Tories.If there were an election tomorrow, Labour would be 31 seats short of a majority but with enough MPs to form a government with Scottish Nationalist support.Tory backing has been sapped as traditional supporters switch to Ukip in protest over the PM’s weak handling of Brexit.There is little to celebrate for any of the party leaders who all get negative popularity ratings.Mr Corbyn scores minus 35, while Theresa May is on minus 26 — only two points better than floundering Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable.Today, a Sun on Sunday poll shows that idea to be total codswallop.Voters simply want our politicians to get on with delivering Brexit.The majority of people have not changed their mind since the referendum.Our poll shows those that have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave.Project Fear has never worked, and it is not going to suddenly start working now. The public are wise to it.Our poll makes it clear that fudging Brexit would unleash serious anger among the electorate. The Government should take notice.Almost half of voters already reckon that the political classes in Britain are making heavy weather of Brexit, in the vain and misguided belief that they can get the public to change their mind.Meanwhile, the drop in support for Theresa May in the polls and Ukip’s rise is a further indication of what the public thought of her Chequers proposals.Millions more will abandon the Tories if Brexit ends up being fudged.Remoaners and Brussels have done their best since the Leave vote to make us think we made a terrible mistake and that the cards are stacked in the EU’s favour.Well, today’s poll is clear.We didn’t and they’re not.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: young women getting 99 botox
story: After all, in the era of Love Island and social media, we’re all potential celebrities now. Even those of us who will never hit the big time have an Instagram audience waiting to “like” our every selfie.So this is just the logical next step towards making cosmetic surgery available to the masses, rather than the few.Some have argued that Superdrug Botox is actually a good thing, because it bridges the gap between the elite Harley Street options — where you pay several hundred pounds for an appointment with an “aesthetic doctor” — and the more backstreet treatments carried out by hairdressers with just a few hours of training.I disagree. Being able to buy a syringe or two of Botox when you are out shopping for your hairspray legitimises — and normalises — the act of injecting poison in your skin in the name of beauty.Being able to buy Botox over the counter, so to speak, makes it seem like no big deal — just another tick in the “maintenance” box, and as reasonable as tinting your lashes or getting your ears pierced.And that is the problem. All decisions we make about our appearance boil down to personal choice. And if it makes someone feel better to tinker cosmetically or surgically with their natural looks, that’s their choice. No one should judge them for it.But there is a wider problem.Increasingly, women think that whatever they look like naturally isn’t good enough. More and more, the “solution” is invasive cosmetic enhancement.A mainstream shop making Botox available for less than 100 quid is surely only going to add to the pressure some women feel to change their appearance using more than just make-up.Superdrug presents itself as responsible because it will refuse to treat under-25s, when other clinics will.That is shocking — not so much that some clinics WILL treat under-25s but that anyone so young could think they need Botox.You can’t blame Superdrug for this epidemic. It is simple supply and demand.The question is: Why the growing desire among women to look frozen?It’s not like you can get away with saying you’ve not had it when you have, because it’s so obvious.I’ve got a friend whose husband jokes that she needs to hold up little signs saying “happy” or “angry” when she feels an emotion, since her face is so paralysed by botulism.While I’m a big believer in your body, your choice, I’m also a believer in scratching the right itch.The truth is if you feel good about yourself, you look good. If you feel bad and lack confidence, nothing, no amount of Botox or fillers, will ever change that.Just look at Meg from Love Island, above, who, even after an estimated £40,000 worth of plastic surgery, is still massively insecure.Because it’s not what’s on the outside that counts, it’s what’s on the inside.The problem is our society tends to give far too much weight to the outside. That is especially the case for women, but increasingly for men, too.I realise all of this is easy to say, harder to act on. I’m as susceptible as the next person to comparing myself with ­others more beautiful — and possibly more airbrushed — and finding myself lacking.I’m just glad that, when that happens, I know the thing that will make me feel better is far more likely to be self-acceptance than Botox.After all, if you tighten a prune you don’t get a grape — you just get a tight prune!So the really big question is, how to achieve self-acceptance when we are surrounded by all these images of perfection?Well, we are all on our own journey with that one but I’ve got some suggestions which might help.The first is to focus on what you have, rather than what you don’t. And the second is to never, ever compare yourself to anyone else.Forget Botox, you can have that advice for free.You’re welcome.We all enjoyed cheering on the Three Lions players that would quickly become our heroes during the World Cup in Russia this summer.Sadly, those heady days are over and we were reminded of the seamier side of sport this week with the arrest of England rugby union ace Danny Cipriani.His embarrassing brawl outside a Jersey nightclub came hot on the heels of England cricket’s Ben Stokes’ trial over his clash with two men during a night out.Stokes was cleared, but what links these sorry sagas is our drinking culture, which dictates that consuming excessive amounts of alcohol is a normal way of letting off steam.Sportsmen are supposed to be role models, as they influence young people and need to keep themselves in good physical shape.But as long as we think it is OK to binge and push our bodies to the limits rather than sip a few drinks, then violence, injuries and stupid mistakes will continue to be a regular feature of our nights out.And if you are an England sports star, then public shame is just one of the tragic consequences – along with the end of your career – that you might have to face.Why should anyone be surprised at the news that sexual harassment in the police force is rife?Let’s face it, it happens everywhere. So why should the police be any exception?I thought they might hold themselves to higher standards. But no.A new survey reveals that dirty jokes, inappropriate touching, leering and being pressured to have sex are daily issues for many police staff.In a survey of almost 1,800 police staff in England, Wales and Scotland, half had heard sexualised jokes and one in five had received a sexually explicit email or text from a colleague.Shockingly, one in five had also been touched in a way that made them feel uncomfortable.Our head of police at West Ham is a woman.She is smart, tough, brave and would never put up with this type of behaviour.Part of the problem is that many women accept these actions as “normal” and don’t even know how to object. We must learn to stop putting up with it.But it is much more important that men learn what is OK and what is not.End of.Jacinda Ardern – the Prime Minister of New Zealand, who has continued to work since becoming a mother in June – was criticised this week for “using her baby as a prop” after she was seen breastfeeding her daughter at a public meeting.I guess whoever coined that phrase has never had the experience of looking after a baby who needs to be fed – right NOW.Nor will they have dealt with the very loud consequences of that failing to happen.Instead, what about congratulating Jacinda on doing such a great job of being a working mum?We said farewell to two legends last week, let’s remember them with this wonderful meme....So interesting that the day after A-level results arrived, more than 26,000 university places were still available.An Ipsos Mori poll found that while most students still think university is “important”, that is down from 86 per cent five years ago to 75 per cent now.Since a degree is expensive – and no guarantee of a job – you can see why people are questioning the validity of one.However, there is no viable alternative.There are just 10,000 degree-level apprenticeships available, compared with 300,000 university places, according to Sir Peter Lampl, of the Sutton Trust.We need to think how we prepare young people for work and we need more technical qualifications at degree level that offer the chance of a bright future.GOT a story? title: remoaners dream second referendum codswallop
story: Today, a Sun on Sunday poll shows that idea to be total codswallop.Voters simply want our politicians to get on with delivering Brexit.The majority of people have not changed their mind since the referendum. Our poll shows those that have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave. Project Fear has never worked, and it is not going to suddenly start working now. The public are wise to it.Our poll makes it clear that fudging Brexit would unleash serious anger among the electorate. The Government should take notice.Almost half of voters already reckon that the political classes in Britain are making heavy weather of Brexit, in the vain and misguided belief that they can get the public to change their mind.Meanwhile, the drop in support for Theresa May in the polls and Ukip’s rise is a further indication of what the public thought of her Chequers proposals.Millions more will abandon the Tories if Brexit ends up being fudged.Remoaners and Brussels have done their best since the Leave vote to make us think we made a terrible mistake and that the cards are stacked in the EU’s favour.Well, today’s poll is clear. We didn’t and they’re not.DEFENCE Secretary Gavin Williamson was right to stand up to France after they tried to bill us £2million for helping them stamp out a jihadi insurrection in Mali.Mr Williamson reportedly threatened to ground our choppers in retaliation. Good.The French also reneged on a deal to support a Nato mission in Estonia.As their closest military ally in Europe, we deserve better.Otherwise, next time, Mr Williamson will be entitled to say: “Zut alors! No more!”IT is scandalous that cops in the capital are reliant on weapon-detecting equipment donated by the public.Knife crime is the most deadly threat our youngsters face on the streets today.This week two men were killed and four teenagers stabbed in separate incidents.How can we expect cops to stamp out this deadly crimewave if they are reliant on public donations?The Government needs to properly start tackling this crisis. Lives depend on it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
