title: dragons den contestants who snubbed
story: NewsDragons' Den contestants who snubbed offer on the show are now making millionsRevellers are now able to compare prices for events thanks to Steve Pearce and Sam Coley's genius ideaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLucy RoueClaire Gilbody-Dickerson15:24, 19 AUG 2018Updated07:24, 20 AUG 2018NewsSteave Pearce (left) and Sam Coley's tech start-up is now making millions (Image: Manchester Evening News)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo Dragons' Den contestants who turned down an offer on the BBC show are now making ten times what they originally bid for. Steve Pearce and Sam Coley, both in their mid 20s, are now making millions since founding their tech product TickX, based at Tower 12 in Spinningfields, in the Northern Quarters of Manchester, Manchester Evening News reports. Their business product, which started garnering traction once backed by the Ministry of Sound, is founded on one basic premise: that humans are social animals who love to be entertained. Founded in 2015, the platform brings together events from 75-plus ticket sellers, including Ticketmaster, Headout and Skiddle, allowing users to compare prices and get the best deal for their night out - through the website and app.  The idea came to Pearce while he studied economics at the University of Manchester and found himself desperately sifting through flyers or scrolling websites for the best prices. He said: “There was a lot of conflicting information from ticket vendors and promoters and that’s when I saw the opportunity. “You look at almost every market globally and there is a billion pound aggregator, so if you are booking a flight you would use Skyscanner, hotels maybe Trivago or car rentals would be Rentalcars. We couldn’t believe that there wasn’t already a local or global firm filling that gap in the market so that’s when we decided to join forces on TickX. I bought a sports car instead of going to university The 26-year-old knew he had the business development and sales expertise but was lacking in the product and tech experience - which is where Coley excels. Having grown up on the west coast of Scotland, 25-year-old Coley admits being obsessed with technology and business from a young age.  “It started off with selling toys to my friends and then chewing gum at school to learning about tech and teaching myself to code. “When I was a bit older I set up an online auction site from my bedroom to sell boats called Bid Marine.” Calling it an ‘unbelievable learning curve’ the youngster headed off to Harvard University for work experience before setting up a software development company aged 15. “I started building websites for local businesses and that grew into app development and big scale projects like cloud software.” However, when his youth became a barrier to getting larger projects, the enterprising youngster took an office in the local town and employed his father. Defying expectations he turned down a place at university to focus on the company and fondly remembers buying his first sports car as his friends settled into student life. Starting up TickX Interested by Pearce’s concept for a ticketing comparison site, the pair set out to build a one-stop destination to discover what events were happening, who was selling tickets and at what price. “While Sam was building the platform on evenings and weekends I was going out and bringing on board ticket partners,” says Pearce. Once the product was built and they started getting traction the founders knew it was time to ‘put their foot on the gas.’ “We believe that fortune favours the bold so we wanted to give it a good shot.” This turned out to be very true as they managed to get Ministry of Sound on board after a cold call.  “It was their first ever tech investment and it was a huge stamp of validation for us having one of the biggest independent record labels in the world back TickX,” he added. Coley chips in brightly: “It allowed us to jump that stage of credibility which a lot of small companies struggle with. People instantly took notice and the name had a massive impact.” Now the platform pulls in 125,000 events from more than 75 ticket partners and prioritises them in order of cheapest first. Last year they sold more than &pound4m of tickets and are on track to grow that significantly. In fact, they have set their sights on building it into a billion pound business here in Manchester. Coley explains: “The opportunity there is massive. Globally it is about &pound160bn a year on experience spend - in the UK it’s &pound7bn all in. “It’s a huge market and if we nail it then it is a massive opportunity - that’s why we are excited and why the investors are excited.” Turning down the Dragons Another reason people have been taking notice is their appearance on BBC hit programme Dragons’ Den where the duo audaciously turned down &pound75,000 investment from three dragons. Filmed in May 2016, Pearce recalls: “We never applied to go on to the show. The researchers actually reached out to us after the Manchester Evening News featured TickX in a top start-ups list.” His business partner says: “As we were already trying to raise investment we had the research to hand on what the problem was and how it needed fixing - so we got invited to audition and two weeks later we were pitching to the dragons.” Comparing it to an ‘intense boxing match’ Coley also praised it as ‘an unreal experience’ - although they didn’t expect to be in the pitch for an hour and a half.  “It was pretty surreal because we had both watched the show since we were young and then to find ourselves in the den was crazy.” This intensified as Nick Jenkins, the founder of online greeting card retailer Moonpig, Touker Suleyman and entrepreneur Peter Jones made them offers. However, the pair felt what they were asking for in equity undervalued the business. “We made the brave, or stupid, decision to decline them,” smiles Pearce. “Actually, we realised there are other people out there who can add value to the business and once they were excited about TickX we could find the capital externally.” This risk paid off, literally, as they ended up raising ten times more than what they had asked for in the den. The &pound750,000 funding round was led by 24 Haymarket giving access to a syndicate of industry leaders and high net worth individuals. They also got some investment from Nick Ferguson, the former chairman of BskyB, and tech innovator Stan Boland, who is devising a self driving car. “We were a young team at the time and we just decided to surround ourselves with the best investors, backers and advisors,” remembers Pearce. His business partner agrees emphatically. “We really want to build an A-class team so the first part of that was getting good investors on board including Tim Chambers, the former Ticketmaster executive, who probably had the best industry knowledge you could ask for.” And this desire to pull in the right mix of investors and business leaders has paid off for the team. “The advice for any young entrepreneur starting in businesses is just to really get out there and get meeting people,” explains Pearce. “Also an investor isn’t always what you think an investor is - one of ours is someone I previously worked with. I think it's important to remember that people invest in an idea and the team which will deliver it.” A second round of funding led by venture capitalists BGF Ventures raised &pound3m and will help accelerate their push into Europe. So where is TickX today? The growth has been pretty significant from a few hundred users when they first launched in the UK to more than one million last year. And the only way is up after expanding into new territories, including Ireland and the Netherlands. Not to mention running the ticketing site for NME. So how does it work? TickX is not a ticket selling platform - instead it helps people discover what is happening and to go out more to live events. I find the co-founders are genuinely passionate about this - and albout making sure people don’t get ripped off. The model works as TickX receives a commission from the ticket partner’s booking fee, making them an additional marketing channel to help reach a wider audience and drive up ticket sales. TickX's audience is a very big mix, the paper reports. “We started off focusing on the student market,” says the Manchester graduate. “Then it was young professionals with gigs before we started to see the huge potential in theatre with high order values and commission.” Coley agrees: “Our vision has changed a lot over the last three years. “We started off by focusing on events and now we really see the whole ‘experience market’. “People are looking to spend less money on things and more on going out and experiencing the world. That’s why the market is exploding. “It’s not just about the Instagram story, people don’t want disposable things any more - they want these experiences.” TickX are looking to innovate around this, launching a cinema offering this month and also building on their tech capabilities.

title: easyjet cancels flight because crew
story: NewsEasyJet cancels flight because 'crew are too tired' leaving holidaymakers in tearsCornelia Dalipe and 15-year-old Erin from West Belfast were among the 146 passengers - and then had to wait another three hours to get homeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCiara Colhoun22:05, 19 AUG 2018NewsCornelia and Erin Dalipe were stunned at the flight cancellation - then had to wait hours to get homeGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother and daughter said they couldn't believe what they were hearing when EasyJet announced their flight to Majorca was cancelled because crew were too tired.  Some of the other holidaymakers - including children - were even in tears when the budget airline made the announcement at the airport last night, reports Belfast Live .  And Cornelia Dalipe and 15-year-old Erin admit they were even more bewildered to find police waiting outside as crew were led out a separate door. EasyJet has since apologised for the crew issue. Cornelia said: We couldn't believe what we were being told. There are many people who work 12-14 hour shifts and just get on with it. The pair from West Belfast were among the 146 holidaymakers looking forward to arriving in Palma on EasyJet flight 6711.  Cornelia claimed they were left stranded at Belfast International Airport when the 8.45pm flight was cancelled around midnight. They were shocked to be told the cancellation was because staff were too tired to go on. Cornelia said there was a police presence in the hall when the passengers were informed they would not be flying after all. She claimed: Police were there even though there was no aggression from passengers and the crew was led out a separate door. She said they then faced another blow when they had to wait hours until 3am before taxis arrived to take them home. She added: There were babies crying and parents of children with special needs trying to find a solution. We all had to queue to be booked onto alternative flights and while we are hoping to fly on Monday night, another woman I was speaking to was in tears as the next available flight for her was Tuesday night, which is a big chunk out of a one-week holiday.  They could have offered to take us over to Majorca without catering so they could have taken turns to sleep. If that meant we were able to get away on our holidays I'd say everyone would have been happy with that. Instead it seemed the flight returned to Palma empty of passengers. People work so hard to get their money together for holidays and look forward to it. Staff seemed fed up too and told us it was an ongoing issue. An EasyJet spokewoman apologised for the cancellation, which she confirmed was due to a crew issue.” She also confirmed there was a taxi delay, which she said was due to various events in the city. However, she insisted it was absolutely not the case that there were structural issues with the flight and said it was the only one cancelled this month.

story: NewsEdinburgh Fringe Festival's funniest joke is gag about being fired from Jobcentre told by former barman - read Top 10Adam Rowe won the 11th annual award for Dave’s Funniest Joke Of The Fringe following in the footsteps of comedy giants Tim Vine, Stewart Francis, Zoe Lyons and Nick HelmShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop08:13, 20 AUG 2018Updated08:19, 20 AUG 2018NewsAdam Rowe won the 11th annual award for Dave’s Funniest Joke Of The Fringe (Image: UKTV Dave/Martina Salvi)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe top ten jokes from this year's Edinburgh Fringe Festival have been revealed - with a gag about being fired from a Jobcentre topping the list. title: jamie oliver slammed mp latest
story: NewsJamie Oliver's jerk rice slammed as 'cultural appropriation' by Labour MPThe TV chef has launched a new range of products, including 'punchy jerk rice' which has so far been a recipe for disaster on social mediaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer18:43, 19 AUG 2018Updated07:19, 20 AUG 2018NewsJamie Oliver has been accused of 'cultural appropriation' (Image: Getty)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJamie Oliver has been slammed by critics on social media over a new range of products that includes punchy jerk rice. People have been quick to point out that jerk seasoning doesn't typically go on rice - but chicken, fish and other meats. The TV chef has been accused of cultural appropriation by people on social media, including Labour MP Dawn Butler, the shadow women and equalities minister. She wrote on Twitter that the celeb's jerk rice is not OK and that his appropriation from Jamaica needs to stop, adding that jerk is not just a word you put before stuff to sell products.      She also wrote that Jamie Oliver should get a masterclass in jerk by Levi Roots, the creator of Reggae Reggae sauce. Jerk is a type of cooking that originates in Jamaica, where meat is dry-rubbed or marinated in a seasoning made up of all spice, scotch bonnets and other ingredients. People accused him of cultural appropriation because the ingredients aren't traditional. One Twitter user wrote: I was about to headbutt my desk over this tweet from Dawn Butler because most cultural appropriation brouhahas are nonsense.  Then I saw this description of Jamie Oliver's Jerk Rice. On what planet can garlic, ginger and jalapenos be described as Jerk?' Some people have been quick to jump to Jamie Oliver's defence: arguing that the UK is a multicultural country and cooking different cuisines isn't the same as cultural appropriation. One person tweeted: Now while I do think Jamie needs taking down a peg or three you're all getting very silly over this appropriation stuff. If no one cooked/ate food from other cultures in the world what a boring life we'd lead.

title: meghan markle just 150 miles
story: NewsMeghan Markle will be just 150 MILES from dad Thomas on visit to see mum - but will they meet to heal rift?Meghan, 37, is jetting to the US to see mum Doria Ragland on a personal holiday - just a short distance from where Thomas Markle Snr, 74, lives over the border in Rosarito, MexicoShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRussell Myers21:30, 19 AUG 2018Updated07:58, 20 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle’s trip to L&shyA could give her the ideal opportunity for a reconciliation with dad Thomas after three months of not talking. But the former Hollywood lighting director has had no word as to whether his daughter is ready to meet him during the solo visit to see her mum. And royal sources have warned Thomas could put any chance of a resolution to their problems at risk if he carries on with his public outbursts and sniping at her and the royals. Meghan, 37, will fly to the US to see mum Doria Ragland on a personal holiday. Thomas, 74, lives 150 miles away across the border in Rosarito, Mexico. He and Meghan have not spoken since her wedding to Prince Harry on May 19, after his staged &shypaparazzi photos scandal was exposed. A royal source said: “The past few weeks will no doubt have been &shyincredible stressful for Meghan and no one wants this saga to continue for her. “Hopefully she can find some way of seeking a resolution with her father but going back to her roots for a few days is exactly what she needs right now.  “Time will tell what the process for any type of relationship may be but as long as they keep hurting her, it becomes more and more unlikely they will be able to have any type of relationship.” A source close to Prince Charles was yesterday quoted saying: “The prince will be very sympathetic towards Meghan and the difficult situation she is in. But I suspect the Queen will be rolling her eyes and thinking, ‘Crikey, what is going to become of all of this?’” Since the staged photos fiasco, Thomas has engaged in a series of &shyexplosive tell-all interviews where he criticised the royal family, revealed &shyintimate details of conversations with Harry and slammed his daughter’s “sense of superiority”. The latest in a string of outbursts came after he “reached his limit” and hit out at his daughter and declared: “You’d be nothing without me.” And he put the phone down on Harry when the prince told him: “If you’d listened to me none of this would have happened.” Despite the public ramblings that have left Meghan deeply embarrassed, Thomas is desperate for a reconciliation with her. He has said: “I love my daughter. I love Prince Harry. I wish them nothing but the best.”  And he yesterday admitted he had made a grave error of judgement in lying to Prince Harry about staging the photos before the Royal wedding. Thomas said: “I made a terrible mistake which I have paid for ever since.” The Mirror last month reported that senior royal aides have held at least three crisis meetings to discuss how to deal with his outbursts. And we also told how Thomas feared he would never see his daughter again because of the drama. Former actress Meghan will meet up with Doria for the first time since her wedding within days. It is thought she may schedule in a visit to Toronto, Canada to see close friends and former co-stars from the hit TV show Suits which she starred in from 2011 as Rachel Zane for six years. She has been in regular contact with Doria and best friend Jessica Mulroney and has taken their advice on what action to take as Thomas and his side of the family continue to embarrass her.  Fashion stylist Jessica and husband Ben, son of former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, live in Toronto and have been two of the duchess’ closest confidantes throughout her &shyrelationship with Harry. Meghan made Jessica &shyunofficial maid of honour and included all three of the couple’s children in the wedding. Harry is not expected to travel to the US with his wife. But it was reported yesterday that “early talks” have taken place about the couple attending a charity polo match in LA or Santa Barbara, California, as part of an &shyAmerican tour next spring. title: meghan markles dad sets record
story: NewsMeghan Markle's dad sets the record straight about 'outright lies' - and why he 'isn't in' first wedding photosThe retired Hollywood lighting director, 74, is angered by rumours including that he is "bitter" that his daughter did not pay back thousands of dollars on her private educationShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth08:50, 19 AUG 2018Updated12:20, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThomas Markle has hit out at a number of outright lies against him, including claims that he is a prescription pill addict and missed Meghan's first wedding before she wed Prince Harry . The retired Hollywood lighting director is also incensed by rumours that he is bitter that his daughter did not pay back thousands of dollars on her private education. Speaking from his home in Rosarito Beach, Mexico, the 74-year-old told the Mail On Sunday: I’ve given just three interviews but there are thousands of stories circulating out there and it’s not right that people should be allowed to make up lies and get away with it. I’ve read stories saying I’m a drug addict or alcoholic. I don’t understand where these stories come from. I’ve taken pills when I’ve been in pain but I’ve never abused drugs.  You couldn’t move in Hollywood in the 1980s [when he worked there] without seeing bowls of cocaine everywhere. But I don’t do drugs and I barely drink. As well as the rumours about addiction, Markle also denied stories that he did not attend Meghan’s 2011 wedding to Hollywood director Trevor Engelson, who she divorced just two years later. While photos from the ceremony in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, show the couple exchanging vows on the beach and Meghan’s mother, Doria Ragland, swimming in the sea, Mr Markle is not visible in any of the pictures. However he reasons that the lack of photos of him at the wedding was because he was well into his 60s and not much into frolicking.  He added that he was present at the ceremony and walked Meghan down the beach with Doria, with 100 other guests also attending. Markle said that while he does have photos of him and his daughter at her first wedding, he chooses not to share them as he feels that it would be in poor taste and would be offensive to Prince Harry. The entire resort had been booked out, and Markle said he contributed to the costs by selling Facebook shares at a low price in order to help out financially. He said: I don’t regret it in the slightest because I was happy to help out, but that stock would be worth a fortune now. I’m not broke, I’m not bitter and I never expected Meghan to pay me back for anything. I was happy as a father to give her a great education. I was happy to provide the best start in life to all my children. Of course I never expected her to pay me back for her schooling.  Meghan has not spoken to her father since Prince Harry phoned him in hospital following his heart attack days before the Royal Wedding on May 19. It has been reported that Harry scolded him during the phone call for working with the paparazzi over staged pictures including one where he was being measured for a wedding suit. During the call, Harry scolded him for co-operating with paparazzi over staged pictures, including one of him apparently being measured for a wedding suit. title: most brits dont know europe
story: NewsMost Brits don't know Europe is a continent - but can you pass our geography test?Amazingly around 1.5million Brits think Great Britain is its own continentShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByStephen JonesDeputy News Editor16:26, 19 AUG 2018NewsMore than half of Brits admit their knowledge of world locations, capital cities or landmarks is ‘ok’ or ‘poor’ (Image: SWNS - Bristol +44 (0)1179066550)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMillions of Brits struggle with basic geography knowledge - with more than one in five unaware Europe is a continent, a study has found. Researchers found two thirds have no idea the world is made up of seven land masses, with one in four wrongly believing there are only five. And three per cent - or the equivalent of 1.5m people - even think Great Britain is its own continent. Another one in four don’t know Antarctica is home to the south pole. The poll was commissioned by British Airways Holidays as A level and GCSE students receive their results. But despite 63 per cent of adults describing themselves as ‘well-travelled’, visiting an average of nine countries each, just one third reckon they would pass GCSE geography if they were to take the exam now.   The study also found 54% of Brits admit their knowledge of world locations, capital cities or landmarks is ‘ok’ or ‘poor’. Almost one quarter think the most commonly spoken language in Brazil is Spanish, rather than the correct answer of Portuguese. And one in four are unable to name the Sahara Desert as the largest hot desert in the world. Sixty-three per cent have no idea there are 50 stars on the US flag and more than one in 10 struggle to name India as the home of the Taj Mahal. And one tenth also think the Canadian city of Toronto is a US state and the same number pin pointed Athens as the home of the famous colosseum instead of Rome. But when it comes to capital cities, Brits do a little better with 78% able to identify Copenhagen as the capital of Denmark and 85% correctly naming Washington D.C as the US capital.  The research polled 9,000 adults from 13 countries, including the US, France, Germany, Russia, Brazil and Australia. One in four Australians struggle to name the Colosseum’s home as Rome, while almost one in five of French respondents and one in 10 Italians aren’t aware their home countries are part of the Alps. Only 54 per cent of Australians correctly said Budapest was the capital of Hungary, whereas UK based respondents fared better with 66 per cent selecting the correct answer. Six in 10 Germans could name India as the home of the Taj Mahal, yet a third of Russians don’t know Brazil’s language is Portuguese.

title: mum 35 who expected home
story: NewsMum, 35, who expected to be home in time for tea dies after routine hospital test goes tragically wrongKate Jones, 35, suffered a fatal heart attack as her husband Stewart, 48, sat in the hospital waiting-room expecting to take her homeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth11:48, 19 AUG 2018Updated13:19, 19 AUG 2018NewsKate Jones, 35, and her devastated husband Stewart, now 48 (Image: South Coast News)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe family of a mum-of-four who suffered a fatal heart attack when a routine test went wrong have won a payout but say hospital bosses are yet to apologise. Kate Jones, 35, went into hospital thinking she would be home to give her children their tea. But crucial errors by doctors triggered two cardiac arrests and she died as her husband Stewart sat in the waiting-room expecting to take her home. He only found out something had gone disastrously wrong when a panicked nurse rushed in asking him for the names of their children - in a bid to get his wife to focus and cling on to life. Shortly afterwards a doctor informed him the simple outpatient procedure had gone so disastrously wrong his wife had tragically died. Mr Jones, 48, said: It was the most horrendous thing. I took my wife to hospital for this test which we thought was perfectly safe and I went home a widower.  The hospital still haven't apologised or even held their hands up and admitted liability and that has been especially hard. It has made everything so much worse. Now he has been awarded &pound700,000 in an out-of-court settlement after a five year legal battle that has left him furious and demoralised with the NHS. Like thousands of others Kate, a highly-regarded beautician who worked for Virgin Atlantic, needed an angiogram to check for narrowing of the arteries. Though she was slim and healthy, she took statins to control high cholesterol levels - a condition which ran in her family. But after suffering a slight heart palpitations she was referred for an angiogram at the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Harlow, Essex. She and her husband were told it was a routine test carried out as an out-patient. On the NHS Choices website it is described as a generally safe and painless procedure. Mrs Jones went for the angiography on October 30 2013, thinking she would be in hospital for a couple of hours and home later the same day. The nightmare that followed is indelibly etched on her husband's mind. He said: She went in feeling a bit nervous but safe in the knowledge it was straightforward day-care procedure. Despite her very occasional heart murmur and high cholesterol, Kate was otherwise fit and full of life, always on the go and running around after the kids.  He drove her to the hospital and sat in the waiting room and the procedure began at about 11am. Mr Jones, is a manager at an electrical wholesalers who lives with their children Siena, 10, Lily, eight, Jaxon, six, in Stanstead Abbotts, Herts. He said: After an hour I saw staff come hurrying from the room looking panicked. It looked like they were running for help and then a specialist went into the room. I knew something had gone wrong but didn't know how dreadful it was until a nurse came out and asked me then names of our children. They wanted this to keep Kate focussed on her children and help her cling to life. I was in total shock. What had tragically occurred was a catalogue of blunders that began when the doctor tore an artery causing her to go into cardiac arrest. The torn artery was serious but not in itself fatal. However, despite the tear being seen, there was a delay of 15 crucial minutes before a heart specialist was called, causing the injury to worsen and Mrs Jones' condition to deteriorate. When the consultant arrived he inserted a guide wire to insert a stent which would have increased blood flow through the artery into the heart. But tragically the connector keeping the guide wire in place broke and, instead of leaving the wire in place and replacing the connector, the surgeon instead pulled the guide wire out meaning the stent could not be deployed. As a result Mrs Jones no blood was getting to the heart, she went into a second cardiac arrest and died at 1.30pm. Devastated and in shock, Mr Jones returned home to break the news to their children Siena, Lily, Jaxon, and Jake - her son from a previous relationship. He said: Kate was the love of my life. She was vibrant, caring and talented, with a unique sense of humour. She was so proud of her kids and she made a lasting impression on everyone who met her. I still find it hard to believe she's not here. Mr Jones is now the sole breadwinner and pays a nanny &pound25,000 a year to look after his children while he is at work. The out-of-court settlement will help provide future financial security for them but came after a five year legal battle with the hospital. No amount of compensation can bring her back and we have to live the rest of our lives without her love, support and zest for life. I brought the action because I desperately want lessons to be learnt from Kate's death and do not want any other family to go through what we have to endure since her untimely death.

title: new mrsa buster can wipe
story: NewsNew MRSA buster can wipe out superbug plaguing hospitals and killing Brits using light beam and oxygen cellsScientists have found a way of using light to turn oxygen into killer cells that attack the antibiotic-resistant bacteria which kills hundreds of patients in Britain every yearShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent22:03, 19 AUG 2018NewsMRSA kills hundreds of Brits every year (Image: Reuters)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailScientists are developing a new way of wiping out the deadly &shyhospital superbug MRSA. Light is used to turn oxygen into killer cells that attack the antibiotic-resistant bacteria. And the method may even work on skin cancer, it is claimed. Researchers are using photosensitisers that contain metal &shynanoparticles to target the MRSA, which kills hundreds of patients in Britain every year. Study chief Dr Peng Zhang said: “Instead of antibiotics, which no longer work against some bacteria like MRSA, we use photosensitisers, mostly dye molecules, that become excited when illuminated with light.  Then, the &shyphotosensitisers convert oxygen into reactive oxygen species that attack the bacteria.” Dr Zhang, of the University of Cincinnati in the US, has a patent related to the design of hybrid photosensitisers, which can be formulated into a spray or gel. His team discovered that the &shyphotosensitisers with the nanoparticle were more effective at killing a variety of bacteria than those without. He added: “If you want to attack a castle and you let people attack individually, it is not very effective. Instead, if you have the same number of people grouped together attacking the castle, it is possible to cause more damage.”

story: NewsPrince Philip, 97, surprises The Queen by travelling to Balmoral after hip replacementThe Duke of Edinburgh, who had the operation in April, also joined Zara and Mike Tindall at the serviceShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly18:11, 19 AUG 2018Updated19:24, 19 AUG 2018NewsIt was Prince Philip and The Queen's first public outing since June (Image: REX/Shutterstock)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Prince Philip joined The Queen at a church service in Balmoral today just months after he had a hip replacement. title: rose west believes forgiven god
story: NewsRose West 'believes she will be forgiven by God' and goes to weekly chapel servicesEXCLUSIVE: The house of horrors killer has been telling fellow prisoners that she will be at peace in an after-life – despite helping her husband Fred kill their daughterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPhil Cardy22:13, 18 AUG 2018Updated08:31, 19 AUG 2018NewsRose West has been boasting to lags (Image: PA Archive/Press Association Images)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email House of horrors killer Rose West has told fellow prisoners she will be forgiven by God.  Britain’s worst female serial &shymurderer – who helped her husband Fred rape their daughter, kill her and bury her under their patio – now goes to weekly chapel services. And the deluded monster, who blames her depraved hubby for &shy“making me do things”, insists she will be at peace in an after-life. The astonishing revelations come from Catherine Jones, 52, who spent time in jail with Rose, 64. And they follow claims this week that more victims of Fred West are buried in Glasgow, where he lived before meeting Rose.  Catherine, 52, who was in HMP Low Newton, Co Durham, with Rose, told the Sunday People : “She really believes she’ll be forgiven when she dies.  “Will she? She put her own daughter under the patio.”  Rose’s religious confession came after she was asked: “What’s it like knowing you’ll be leaving this place in a wooden box?” Catherine said: “She came to me and my mates and said, ‘I’ve found a new life in God.’” Rose, who was convicted of ten murders including her daughter Heather, has embraced religion so firmly she visits the prison chapel every Sunday. But last night a close family member told the Sunday People: “We’re trying to move on and if Rose thinks that asking God to forgive her will in some way make up for what she’s done then that’s not a god that I would understand.  “There is nothing she can do that would put right what happened. “Really I think that it’s disrespectful to the families because they’re &shynever going to get closure.” Fred and Rose killed, dismembered and buried young women and children at 25 Cromwell Street, Gloucester. Fred, 53, hanged himself in jail on New Year’s Day 1995 while awaiting trial for 12 murders between 1967 and 1987. Rose is serving a whole life tariff after being convicted in 1995. Ex-inmate Catherine, freed in June after serving 19 years for killing a man in Liverpool, said: “Rose blamed Fred for &shyeverything. She said he bullied her and made her do things.”  Catherine gave a graphic description of Rose’s &shybehaviour in Low Newton. She said: “Rose was the main woman in there but she did get stick because of who she is. “She was treated &shydifferently. I’d say it was preferential treatment. The more &shynotorious prisoners got that. Rose was clever, manipulative, clued up. That’s how she got favourable treatment. “She’d bake cakes for the girls. She was allowed to shower on her own, she didn’t have to go with everyone else. “We had ‘social’ every day where we would sit round smoking and chatting. Rose walked past and we shouted ‘Rose, give us a minute.’  “It was when she came over that someone said, ‘What’s it like knowing you’ll leave here in a wooden box?’ “That’s when she came out with all this stuff about ‘finding God’ and being ‘forgiven by God’ and ‘Fred made me do it.’ We couldn’t believe it. “She was blaming him but we all knew what she’d done. Rose does go to chapel every Sunday. She may be trying to find something by doing that but I don’t know what – after &shyeverything she’s done.” Catherine said Rose was allowed her own area where she could do sewing. “It was her sewing room and she made a little tapestry for the door &shysaying Threads Room. “But when she was away we messed about with it and changed it to Fred’s Room. “When she came back she just shook her head and took it down.  “Another time she was playing music in the cell. She was playing When Will I See You Again by The Three Degrees. “At the end of each chorus we were all shouting ‘Fred!’.” Catherine added: “She did get stick, but she was the main woman, she ruled the roost. I wasn’t intimidated by her like others. She knew I spoke my mind.” Catherine also spoke about Rose’s lesbian affairs. “She had a few girlfriends in there, different relationships. “She’d make cakes for the girls. She loved the kitchen, she used to eat a lot. She grassed me up once. I was banned from the kitchen but I snuck in to get some food and she grassed on me for it.” Catherine told how Rose tried to get all the TV sets removed when a &shydocumentary about her horrific crimes was due to be screened. “She tried to get all the tellies turned off. It was because there was a &shyprogramme on about her and Fred. “They wouldn’t do it and the next day she wouldn’t come out of her cell. “She didn’t want to talk to anyone because she knew we’d all been watching.” Catherine also told how Rose had “dead eyes”.  She said: “She walked round &shylooking at the floor, not making eye contact. She had dark eyes. Most people have a little sparkle in their eyes, but hers were cold, dead.” Catherine, who was convicted with another person of robbing and killing a man in a B&ampB, added: “I really regret what I was involved in. My family was gutted. “But Rose is totally &shydeluded trying to blame Fred for everything.” This week calls were made to reinvestigate Fred’s life in Glasgow in the 1960s. Fred was working as a Mr Whippy ice-cream man when he ran over and killed a three-year-old boy in 1965. Paul Pender, a screenwriter who has researched Fred’s crimes, claims there is evidence that he deliberately hit the child. The author has been discussing the case with a man who worked in a Glasgow abattoir with Fred’s first wife Rena – &shymurdered by Fred in 1971. Pender believes Fred used his shed at the allotment to have sex with girls after luring them into his ice-cream van. He also believes Fred learned butchery skill to dismember his victims’ bodies after visiting the abattoir where Rena worked. After leaving Scotland Fred returned to Gloucester, where he went on a murdering spree with Rose, whom he married in 1972.  Last night the Ministry of Justice &shydeclined to comment.  Terror at 25 Cromwell St  Rose West murdered at least ten girls with her husband Fred, dismembering their bodies and burying them under their house of horrors at 25 Cromwell Street, Gloucester. Rose met Fred, who was 13 years older, at Cheltenham bus station when she was 15. Rose’s first murder, in June 1971, was Fred’s step-daughter from his first marriage, Charmaine, aged eight. At the time Fred was in prison for theft. A friend revealed when they visited the house Charmaine was standing on a chair with her hands tied behind her back with a belt. Rose was holding a large wooden spoon and about to hit her. She later said Charmaine had been naughty and had to be punished. After killing her, Rose told people she had “gone to live with her mother and bloody good riddance”. Another victim was daughter Heather, 16. The couple would tell their other children if they didn’t behave they would “end up under the patio like Heather”. Their sickening crimes began to unravel in 1992 when Fred was accused of raping his 13-year-old daughter. Shocked cops soon discovered the couple had been abducting girls from bus stops around Gloucester and holding them captive before killing them. Police discovered mutilated bodies buried in the garden and cellar of their home, which has since been demolished. Victims  1967: Ann McFall, Scottish nanny and Fred’s lover, eight months pregnant.    1970: Rena Costello, Fred’s first wife.   1972: Charmaine West, eight.    1973: Linda Gough, 21, seamstress from Gloucester.    1973: Lucy Partington, 21, university student.   1974: Carol Cooper, 15, from Worcester.    1975: Juanita Mott, 19, of Newent, Glos.    1975: Shirley Hubbard, 15, from Worcester.    1977: Therese Siegenthaler, 21, Swiss hitchhiker.    1977: Alison Chambers, 17, from Swansea.    1978: Shirley Robinson, 18, Fred’s pregnant lover.   1987: Heather West, 16, eldest daughter.

story: NewsSuperdry co-founder donates £1m to have second Brexit referendum - and Leavers are lividJulian Dunkerton has donated £1m to campaign for a second vote on Brexit, and believes there's a "genuine chance to turn this around"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer13:00, 19 AUG 2018NewsJulian Dunkerton is one of the co-founders of fashion brand Superdry (Image: Getty Images Europe)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe campaign for a vote on the UK's final Brexit deal has received a record donation - a whopping &pound1m. Julian Dunkerton, co-founder of Superdry, said he's making the enormous donation to the People's Vote campaign because he sees a genuine chance to turn this around.  Writing in the Sunday Times , he said: I'm putting some of my money behind the People’s Vote campaign because I know we have a genuine chance to turn this around.  I've got a good instinct for when a mood is going to change and we’re in one of those moments now. title: super saver woman saved 15000
story: NewsSuper savvy woman saves £15,000 and even buys a house after collecting discount couponsSavvy Clair Hughes, 30, started researching ways to save money as a way of getting out of her £3,500 overdraft before stumbling upon a 'couponing' community onlineShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByErin Cardiff07:56, 20 AUG 2018Updated08:25, 20 AUG 2018NewsClair estimates she's saved over £15,000 (Image: PA Real Life)Get Money Deals updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman saved &pound15,000 and bought a house after collecting thousands of discount coupons online. Savvy Clair Hughes, 30, started researching ways to save money as a way of getting out of her &pound3,500 overdraft. During her search, Clair, from Bury, Greater Manchester, stumbled upon a 'couponing' community online - and was hooked. Clair now estimates she’s saved “easily over &pound15,000” - and even managed to put down a deposit to buy a three-bed semi-detached house with her partner, Shane Byrne, also 30. Revealing how she never pays full price for an item anymore, thrifty Clair, who works in a local school, said: “It’s become a running joke with my friends. Every time we go out, they’ll ask if I have a voucher – and I always do. “Discounts are always there to be had, it’s just a matter of being organised.  “Before I started this, I thought it’d be so much work, but now I’m so used to this lifestyle that it’s automatic to me. I must have saved easily over &pound15,000.” Clair’s mind first turned to money saving back in 2010, when she moved in with Shane, a phone company trainer. Having recently graduated from Edge Hill University, near Wigan, where she studied drama and physical theatre, she’d maxed out her &pound3,500 student overdraft – and felt the interest repayments were just “money down the drain.” After taking to the web for advice, she tried out a few clever money saving tricks like switching her overdraft to a zero-interest account. Then, a few years later, she came across an online community for “couponers” and decided to give it a go.  She started spending hours trawling the web for money off vouchers or discount codes, printing them all out to take with her whenever she went shopping. “It would initially take a couple of hours to get organised,” she said. “I’d go on supermarket websites to look through what I’d need in a shop, making a note of anything on offer, or anything I had a coupon for. “Eventually though it becomes second nature and you can do it in around half an hour.” Over the years, the coupon queen has managed to nab some impressive hauls. Two lamps worth &pound140 cost her just &pound35, and because she learnt buying in bulk is usually cheaper, she scored six months worth of dog food for her Pomeranian Poppy for a mere &pound9. Around two years ago, Clair also began using cashback apps and websites where you are given money back on items ranging from beers to toiletries.  After each shop, she uploads pictures of her receipts, which are then scanned, and money is given back on certain items. “I’ve saved hundreds through that alone,” said bargain-mad Clair. “You can get cashback on most things, and it’s all something I’d have been buying anyway. If something is totally free, I always make sure I get it regardless of whether I’ll use it, as I can donate it to a charity or foodbank. “But with cashback, I make sure it’s worth my while.” Among her other top saving tips, Clair recommends taking part in paid online surveys, which have earned her hundreds in high street vouchers, hitting the shops at certain times of the day to take advantage of reduced ‘yellow sticker’ stock, signing up to receive trials or tester products or trawling cosmetics counters for freebies. She added: “I have managed to get a lot of freebies by messaging or writing to companies to compliment them on their products. People always assume you get freebies for complaining – but it pays more to be nice.  “I’ve heard a lot about a practice called wombling too, which is basically collecting other people’s discarded receipts from shopping trolleys to check for missed discounts. I’d love to give it a try but there doesn’t seem to be a receipt to be found at my local supermarket.” Having set herself the goal of owning a home by the time she was 30, Clair - who has set up an Instagram dedicated to sharing her thrifty pearls of wisdom - was delighted to exchange just five days shy of her landmark birthday. And now, after Shane proposed to her on his birthday earlier in August, she is looking ahead to planning the ultimate shoestring wedding.

title: tragic mystery baby girl found
story: NewsTragic mystery of baby girl found dead in a sack on riverbank is yet to be solved 16 years onAmanda would have celebrated her 16th birthday this year had she been aliveShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGayle McDonaldColleen Smith09:09, 19 AUG 2018Updated09:12, 19 AUG 2018NewsAmanda's death shook the whole community (Image: Plymouth Herrald WS)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mystery case of a newborn baby girl found in a sack weighed down by bricks near a river in South Devon is yet to be unravelled 16 years on. To this day police still don't know whether the 9lb baby died of natural causes or if she was victim of something more sinister.  Investigators said back when the tiny body was found 16 years ago that whoever was responsible for abandoning it must have been a local as the spot along the River Teign could only have been found by someone who knew it was there, reports Plymouth Herald .  Named by police as Amanda, which means worthy of love, the newborn child with a mass of black hair was discovered by local fisherman Barry Kingwell at Arch Brook Creek on the Teign estuary near Coombe Cellars, South Devon, in September 2002.  He was checking his crab pots at around 8am, when he spotted a sack in the reeds. Inside the sack was a dark-haired, baby girl. The baby had been wrapped in a man-made white hessian sack, which had been placed into a similar larger bag. Both bags were weighed down with a house brick. A post-mortem examination revealed that the 9lb baby was born alive and healthy. Nobody knows if she was dead when she was left in the creek or if she was left there to die. Despite numerous police appeals, no parents or relatives were found.  But a DNA sample was taken from Amanda’s tiny body and through careful examination of the site where she was found and material discovered, police have been able to establish a full DNA profile of the mother. To identify the parents, police needed a friend, relative or anyone who has the remotest suspicion to get in touch. Nobody came forward. To this day the case remains a mystery. A year after the shocking discovery, the people of Teignmouth and police who worked on the investigation remained incredibly moved by the sad discovery. As a mark of respect they installed a marble plaque in tribute to the mystery infant, who medical experts say died within days of her birth. Standing beside the plaque inscribed with the words: “A tiny flower lent not given, to bud on earth and bloom in heaven”, Detective Sergeant Ken Lamont, who led the investigation, said he hoped the tribute to the baby might prompt someone to break their silence.  Sadly, it didn't. To this day nobody knows if the baby died by natural causes or was left to die. Speaking 15 years ago DS Lamnont said: “While the case remains in the public domain there is always a chance of the mother or someone with knowledge of the matter to come forward. “But at such a time we thought that a headstone or plaque would be a fitting end to this tragic incident. “It is unusual to have a common grave marked, although Teignbridge District Council felt the tragedy had affected the hearts and minds of the local community and were happy to allow the erection of the memorial.” He added: “We still do not know yet whether this baby died out of natural causes or whether it was something more sinister, but so far all of our leads to find the mother, father or a relative, have turned out negative. Police were convinced that the mother and father lived locally.  They said that the spot on the River Teign where the body was found would be difficult to find unless you knew it was there and said that the bags could only be bought by local people. “Concealed births are very common but this is very rare as where the baby was deposited is not easy to get to and the mother would not have been able to get there on her own,” said DS Lamont. “It is likely that a third party was involved. But we need to find out what happened. “It could be that the mother was very vulnerable and unaware of what was happening in the birth process itself and unknown to her, or it could be that she is a juvenile who did not know which way to turn.

title: uk weather forecast sunshine set
story: NewsUK weather forecast: Sunshine set to return after Storm Ernesto wind and rain - but bank holiday still 'uncertain'This week will see the warm weather return with temperatures reaching the high 20C’s in the south east on Tuesday and WednesdayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNatalie Evans04:00, 20 AUG 2018Updated04:24, 20 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrits hoping for a scorching end to summer will be taking a gamble on the weather for this week’s bank holiday weekend. Forecasters say there is “huge uncertainty” with large parts of the UK facing the possibility of unsettled wet weather or a return to heatwave conditions. Yesterday, the remnants of Storm Ernesto swept across the UK bringing heavy rain to many parts of the country. As it crossed the Azores the Atlantic storm brought winds of 45 mph but slowed as it reached our shores.  This week will see the warm weather return with temperatures reaching the high 20C’s in the south east on Tuesday and Wednesday. The weather will remain rather cloudy in the north-west with rain. On Thursday, fresher conditions with showers in the north, rain for central parts.  But another weather front heading in from the Atlantic on Friday has the potential to bring in heavy rain over the long weekend break, particularly in south Wales and south west England. Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: “Computer simulations are picking up on something that is just happening thousands of miles away over to the west of the North American continent. “The south ridge in the jet stream here could start to happen and if that happens then it will have big downstream consequences on the weather at home because this ridge will then ripple all the way across North America, the north Atlantic and then under close to the UK. “If we end up on the south of this ridge we will have similar weather to what we had earlier in the summer – the heatwave, the dry, the heat, the high pressure.

title: uk weather met office forecast
story: NewsUK weather Met Office forecast: Brits to swelter again with temperatures soaring to 28C in the southThe UK will return to more humid, muggy weather in the run-up to the last Bank Holiday weekend of the yearShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByClaire Gilbody-Dickerson19:43, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The UK is braced for another bout of hot, sticky weather with temperatures soaring in the south by midweek, according to the Met Office.  After a brief respite and some very welcome rain, the country will return to more humid, muggy weather in the run-up to the last Bank Holiday weekend of the year. Monday will begin with sunny spells in Scotland and northern England. Central areas will see spots of rain with cloud building in the north and rain spells expected after 12pm. But the Met said they won’t be “long-lived or heavy”, and that light winds will bring temperatures in the north to 22C and 26C in the south.   Yet the cooler weather isn’t bound to last long as the Met Office said it will be “quite humid and muggy through Tuesday and Wednesday”.  Highs of 26C are expected in the north, while the south may reach 27C or 28C depending on the sunshine. Londoners are also set for another 25C heatwave on Wednesday, but the Met said it’ll feel fresher because of rain, before it cools down to 20C on Friday.  It comes after the UK was battered by Storm Ernesto over the weekend, with the north being the worst hit and the Met forecasting up two-and-a-half inches of rain.     Met Office forecaster Steven Keates said: “Ernesto’s warm and humid air stays here for the first half of the week, with 26-28C from Monday to Wednesday in the South, with mainly dry weather for most. “A cold front brings rain on Thursday, but the Bank Holiday weekend looks relatively warm at 23C and a degree or two warmer not ruled out. “The South will be mainly dry, and the North still seeing good sunny spells, but less settled.” UV levels will be high or moderate across the country, while pollen levels will remain low. Summer 2018 has a chance of ending up the warmest on record for the UK, with the race for the top spot wide open, according to the Met Office.

title: upton park shoppers wrestle blade
story: NewsUpton Park shoppers wrestle blade from hands of knifeman before he is pinned to the floorA knife was wrestled from a teenager after he allegedly stabbed a man in the middle of a busy street in broad daylightShare&nbspByLaura Forsyth13:52, 19 AUG 2018Updated14:03, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHero bystanders are seen wrestling a knife from a youth after he allegedly stabbed a man in the hand in the middle of a east London high street. A shocking video clip shows two men trying to grab the weapon off a the suspect in broad daylight near Upton Park Tube station. Terrified passersby look on as the youth pushes the group from the pavement, and into the path of approaching traffic. Another then bravely runs to their help and attempts to stop the suspect holding the knife. Dashcam footage shows the incident happening behind a bus in the middle of Green Street, shortly before 1pm on Saturday.  A man with a shopping bag and a fourth stop and join the struggle as they attempt to grab the knife safely out of the way. Another appears to have been hurt by the knife and runs off the road, where a queue of cars are waiting. Then the clip shows the group of men, who appear to be in their 30s and 40s, holding onto the suspect until a another person in grey tracksuit bottoms takes the knife from him. Finally the weapons spins dramatically through the air. Near the end of the video, the youth is seen throwing another bystander onto a car.  Then one of the group places the knife safely back in the scabbard. A second clip shows one of the men who helped holding his bleeding hand with a bandage. Meanwhile police appear to hold the suspect to the ground, which is covered with blood. A Met Police spokesman said: Police in Newham were called to Green Street, E13 at 12:50hrs on Saturday, 18 August following reports of a fight.

title: voice mirror stop pwc cashing
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: 'Stop PwC cashing in on Carillion'The scandal of private contractor Carillion’s collapse goes from bad to worse with the revelation accountancy giant Price Waterhouse Coopers is charging up to £1,156 an hourShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByVoice of the Mirror01:18, 20 AUG 2018NewsopinionThe Carillion saga continues (Image: Liverpool Echo)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe scandal of private contractor Carillion’s collapse goes from bad to worse as the vultures feed on the corpse of a firm which owes taxpayers a fortune and left thousands of workers without jobs. Accountancy giant PwC charging up to &pound1,156 an hour feels as excessive as the Unite union claims, especially when concerns about the company’s previous work were raised by MPs Frank Field and Rachel Reeves, joint heads of a Parliamentary inquiry that accused the auditor of a conflict of interest. Field’s dig that PwC had “every incentive to milk the Carillion cow dry” is reinforced by the eyewatering invoices. The insistence by a financial behemoth that the cost would otherwise be higher will only infuriate victims of a terrible corporate failure. Carillion was an ugly face of capitalism, run for the benefit of a few at the price of the many. PwC is not covering itself in glory.  Theresa May has not just abandoned a Tory promise to get rid of mixed sex hospital wards but gone in total reverse. Close on 15,000 patients had to share wards with the opposite sex last year, a betrayal of 2010 and 2015 Tory manifesto promises. Uncaring May does not seem to care about stripping NHS patients of their privacy. What might be acceptable occasionally in exceptional emergencies is not OK when it happens because of poor management or because austerity cuts have forced hospitals to shed beds. Until the Tories sort simpler problems such as the banning of mixed wards they have no chance of finding a cure for the bigger issues.

title: why deleted tinder after week
story: News'Why I deleted Tinder after a week even though I found it's not just loads of people looking for easy sex'Katie-Ann Gupwell tried the dating app and said: "I thought Tinder was rife with people sending unwanted explicit images, flirting and basically finding people to have sex with"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKatie-Ann Gupwell07:32, 20 AUG 2018Updated07:37, 20 AUG 2018NewsKatie-Ann Gupwell gave Tinder a go for a week (Image: Katie-Ann Gupwell)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKatie-Ann Gupwell, a reporter at MirrorOnline's sister website WalesOnline, went on Tinder for a week - this is what happened in her words: When people find out I'm 24 and single, I get told a lot: You should get on Tinder. In truth I'd never fancied it myself, but in 2018, Tinder and other apps, like Bumble, seem to be the way to meet people. Personally I prefer talking to faces instead of typing on a screen - and there's something that's quite scary about the idea of meeting someone that you've never met in person. But I downloaded it in an attempt to see what the modern world of dating is really like, and recounted the experience on Wales Online.  As little as two weeks ago, I thought Tinder was rife with people sending unwanted explicit images, flirting and basically finding people to have sex with. But apparently it's not (just) about that. Still, all over the internet, there are horror stories about people's experiences. One woman described being sent a picture of a penis with a measuring tape next to it by a guy she met, another described being given chlamydia by a guy who she later found out was already in relationships with two other women. In Wales, a would-be consultant harassed a woman he met on Tinder, sending her emails and hacking her Facebook account . While cases like this may be rare (at least, I hope they are), there's still good reason to be wary and it was hard to go into this with confidence. But at least you can't send pictures on the app. I found this out from a fellow user about an hour after downloading it - for that to happen I would have to add them on another form of social media such as Snapchat or Instagram . Sweet joy! I did not have to put myself through seeing genitals of various shapes and sizes for the purpose of this experiment. Saying that, the fear soon upped when I accidentally super-liked about three people in the space of the first hour. Not ideal.  From the get-go I knew I was never going to meet up with anyone - but as soon as I started swiping I could see what to avoid: 1. People without profile pictures. Why would you not show your face? 2. People with odd profile pictures. I saw everything from a set of sex toys to a quote that read 'I want to do bad things to you' to a chicken nugget. An actual chicken nugget. None of which encouraged me to swipe right. 3. People who had their hands down their pants in pictures. 4. People who are open about wanting hook-ups in their bios. If you like a six pack - you'll see a lot of them on Tinder. There are a lot of guys who post topless pictures of themselves or snaps of them working out at the gym. A lot also posted selfies with their dogs (I know what you're trying to do!) and kids, before quickly pointing out they were their nephews or nieces (Hey, I love kids but I don't have any of my own). During my short stint, I had one or two requests to add guys on Instagram but I gracefully declined. What I found more intriguing is that a lot of people don't actually talk on Tinder.

title: chris watts showed telltale signs
story: NewsChris Watts showed telltale signs of guilt and deception during interviews, says body language expertWatts appeared on TV channels making a plea for the safe return of his family the day before he admitted to killing themShare&nbspByLaura Forsyth16:41, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father accused of killing his wife and two children showed telltale signs that he was lying when he appeared on TV pleading for their safe return, according to a body language expert. Chris Watts, 33, will face court on Monday charged with murdering daughters Bella and Celeste and wife Shanann. She was 15-weeks pregnant with a baby boy that they were going to name Nico.  Last week he sobbed on TV as he appealed for the return of the trio before allegedly confessing he had killed them. The bodies were found on the property of Anadarko Petroleum, one of Colorado's largest oil and gas drillers where Watts worked.  Body language experts who closely studied the recordings of the interviews believe that it was apparent that the 'killer' dad was lying.  Lillian Glass told HollywoodLife that Watts' dishonesty was evident as he spoke too much and was giving out too much information.   She said: He is shrugging his shoulders, which shows he was lying. He smiles and chuckles during the plea, which is very contrived and also reveals he is being fake. Glass adds that Watts, who was arrested on Thursday was showing inappropriate facial responses. He has his arms crossed at one point. The bottom line is, he’s closing off because he knows he’s done something bad. Shanann, 34, Bella, 4, and Celeste, 3, were reported missing on Monday by Watts who made a tearful TV plea to find them.  But things took a sinister turn when he allegedly confessed to killing them. Court papers state that he strangled his two kids before hiding their bodies in oil tanks and burying their mother in a shallow grave.  Prosecutors said they believe the family were murdered in the family home and the bodies were later moved. Police are remaining tight lipped about the cause of death and whether the children were still alive when Shanann was killed. It has also emerged how Shanann had express concerns to her friends that her husband was being unfaithful to her.  Shanann was reported missing on Monday after returning home from a business trip at around 1am. Watts had spent the weekend at home with their children. Chris said he last saw his wife at 5.15am before he left for work.  Speaking on NBC's Today show , Watts said he and Shanann had had an emotional conversation that morning and had stayed up talking but didn't give any further details.  He said: I don't feel like this is even real right now. It's like a nightmare I can't wake up from. He said Shanann was planning to go to a friend's house with their daughters and Fox 31 reports that was the last time he heard from her.

title: lombok earthquake bali indonesia tremor
story: NewsLombok earthquake: Indonesia rocked by 6.9 tremor causing 'fear' and 'worry' for holidaymakers on neighbouring BaliIt is said to have jolted buildings on the island and further 'significant' damage is expectedShare&nbspByBradley Jolly17:00, 19 AUG 2018Updated17:54, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo more powerful earthquakes have rocked Lombok in Indonesia within minutes — leaving terrified tourists again fleeing for safety.  The first tremor, magnitude 7.2 on the Richter scale, hit at a depth of 1km, the U.S. Geological Survey says. It is said to have jolted buildings on the island and further significant damage is expected. Just 30 minutes later a 5.9 tremor struck. An earthquake earlier this month killed hundreds. Twitter users in Indonesia have reported houses dancing like crazy and power cuts during the last tremors. Are you in the area and felt the earthquake? Email webnews@trinitymirror    Other terrified witnesses have reported mudslides. No injuries or fatalities have so far been reported after the latest jolts, but aftershocks have been felt right across the Indonesian islands, including popular tourist destination Bali. Holidaymakers said on Twitter they have felt worried and fear for their safety. Footage shared online shows tourists pouring out of their hotels and into streets as they felt the jolt.  Lombok was hit by an number of aftershocks which caused further trauma and panic for those who lost loved ones or their homes in the disaster earlier this month, as terrified people ran into the streets fearing their homes would fall on top of them. Last month's massive earthquake killed at least 347 people and put the island on the verge of a humanitarian crisis. More than 13,000 homes collapsed or were badly damaged. The tremor was strong enough to rock the neighbouring island of Bali, which is visited by thousands of British tourists every year. The scale of the earthquake was so big that neighbouring Australia was issued a tsunami watch warning for parts of its western coast.  Holidaymaker Charlotte Neal, who was in Ubud, said: “We were travelling in the car in a narrow side street when people started running from shops and shouting. Our driver was Balinese and told us they were shouting ‘earthquake’. “He turned the engine off and we felt the car shake for about 10 seconds, before calming again. The 26-year-old, who lives in Surrey, added: “It was really strange, people then seemed unfazed and went about their business as normal.
